Course Title: Earthquake Resistant Design of Masonry Structures
Course Description: This course explores the fundamental principles of earthquake-resistant design for masonry structures, addressing their inherent seismic vulnerability. It meticulously examines the material properties and complex behavior of masonry under various actions, including compression, tension, shear, and bending, especially under seismic loading. Students will analyze common failure modes observed in past earthquakes and understand codal provisions for seismic safety. The curriculum covers the design of strengthening components and delves into advanced techniques for assessing the seismic safety of existing masonry buildings, equipping students to recommend and implement effective retrofit measures.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Introduction to masonry, Masonry buildings in India, Material properties, Masonry units, Manufacturing process, Mortar, Grout, and reinforcement; Masonry assemblages, Masonry systems, Various tests, and standards.

Unit 2: Masonry under compression: Prism strength, Failure mechanism, types of construction and bonds, Eccentric loading, Slenderness effective length and effective height, effect of openings, Code provisions, masonry in tension, flexural strength of masonry, shear and bending capacity of masonry.

Unit 3: Behavior of masonry structures during past earthquakes: Common modes of failures, effect of roof and floor systems, Masonry under lateral loads: In-plane and out-of-plane loads, bending parallel and perpendicular to bed joints, Shear and flexure behavior of piers, Test and standards, lateral force distribution for flexible and rigid diaphragms, Combined axial and bending actions.

Unit 4: Earthquake Resistant Measures: Analysis for earthquake forces, role of floor and roof diaphragm, Pier analysis using equivalent stiffness approach, Concept and design of bands, splints and bandages, Vertical reinforcement at corners and jambs, Code provisions.
Unit 5: Retrofitting of masonry building: Techniques of repair and retrofitting of masonry buildings, IS: 13935 provisions for retrofitting, different strengthening methodologies and techniques
Generated_LOs: CO1: Analyze material property data (compressive strength, tensile behavior, modulus of elasticity) of masonry units and mortars to calculate allowable stress limits under seismic loading per IS 13935.

CO2: Design a diaphragm system (roof or floor) for a multi‑storey masonry building that satisfies lateral load distribution criteria established in IS 13935, including calculation of equivalent stiffness and reinforcement detailing.
CO3: Evaluate failure mechanisms observed in past earthquake‑recorded masonry structures by correlating observed damage patterns with seismic load paths and detailing critical joint orientations.

CO4: Construct detailed retrofit plans using split‑band and split‑splint techniques, specifying material selection, reinforcement layout, and anchorage requirements to achieve seismic compliance for an existing masonry building compliant with IS 13935.

CO5: Apply the equivalent stiffness approach to analyze combined axial and bending actions in a masonry pier subjected to in‑plane lateral loads, and compute required reinforcement area to resist ultimate shear and moment capacity.
CO6: Demonstrate the use of finite element modeling (ABAQUS or OpenSees) to simulate the nonlinear behavior of a masonry wall under cyclic loading, and interpret results to validate code provisions.

Course Description: This foundational course in practical electronics provides hands-on experience with essential lab equipment and electronic components. Students will engage in designing, implementing, and analyzing both analog and digital circuits on breadboards. The curriculum progresses to circuit simulation using industry-standard software like Multisim, followed by mastering practical soldering techniques for permanent circuit assembly. A significant focus is placed on understanding software-hardware interfaces through controller board integration. This course equips students with comprehensive skills to design, simulate, build, and verify functional electronic systems.
Detailed Syllabus: 1. Know your equipment and components - Lab Equipment and components familiarization such as Power supply, Signal Generator, Oscilloscope, Breadboard, Transistor, Resistor etc...
2. Design, Implementation and Analysis - Implement circuits such as Voltage Regulator record, analyse and interpret the results.
3. Electronic Circuit Design Simulation Software - Learning to install and use Multisim. Design one of the earlier experiments on Multisim and compare hardware and simulation results.
4. The Art of Soldering - Solder one of the implemented circuits now on a general-purpose PCB/Vector Board, record results, compare with the previous implementation on the bread board.
5. Hardware Software Symbiosis - Use of controller boards to interface with electronic circuits and actuators, showcase the need for software-hardware interplay
Generated_LOs: CO1: Design a voltage regulator circuit in Multisim, construct the equivalent breadboard prototype, and demonstrate that the measured dropout voltage is within 5% of the simulation result.
CO2: Solder a low‑pass filter circuit onto a PCB, then record and compare the measured frequency response with the Multisim prediction to show less than 2 dB deviation.
CO3: Configure an Arduino controller to read an analog sensor, process the data, and actuate a relay, thereby proving functional software‑hardware integration.
CO4: Analyze oscilloscope traces of a transistor‑based switching circuit to identify at least two sources of signal distortion and propose corrective measures.
CO5: Evaluate the thermal performance of a switching regulator versus a linear regulator under identical load conditions, and report efficiency differences within 1.5% accuracy.
CO6: Compare simulation parameter settings with the experimental results for a band‑pass RC filter, achieving a phase shift discrepancy below 10 degrees.
CO7: Demonstrate laboratory safety by correctly setting power supply limits and measuring component temperatures during operation, ensuring all readings are below specified thresholds.

Course Description: This workshop delves into the practical design and implementation of embedded systems within an Internet of Things (IoT) framework. It systematically covers sensor/actuator interfacing, microcontroller programming, and diverse communication protocols like Zigbee, WiFi, and MQTT. Students will explore embedded system architectures, cloud-based data storage, and essential considerations for data privacy, security, and interoperability. The curriculum further encompasses PCB design, mechanical enclosure fabrication, and data visualization techniques. Upon completion, participants will possess the skills to develop, assess, and fabricate functional IoT solutions for complex, real-life applications.
Detailed Syllabus: 1. Sensing/Actuators and Interfacing: Sensor/Actuator selection, Physics of sensors, Interfacing (Serial interfaces, Analog out, SPI, UART, I2C).
2. Controller, Embedded Systems and Peripherals: Platform selection (ATMEL328, ESP32, STM8), Embedded Systems (power management, interrupts, memory managements, OTA), Peripherals (RTC, ADC channels).
3. Communications, Networking and IoT Architecture: Different IoT communication protocols (Zigbee/WiFi/BLE/4G/5G/eSim/LoRaWAN), Data Protocols (MQTT/HTTPS/COAP).
4. Data Storage and Computation: Cloud storage and computing, Data retrieval optimization, IoT standards for interoperability.
5. PCB and Enclosure Design.
6. Data privacy and security.
7. Dashboard and Visualization: Software/Approaches (UI/UX, Time Series Data Visualization).
8. Documentation
Generated_LOs: CO1: Design and implement a multi-sensor IoT node using ESP32, integrating temperature, humidity, and light sensors via I2C, and transmit data over MQTT to a cloud endpoint.

CO2: Evaluate power‑management strategies on a battery‑powered embedded platform by measuring current draw under different sleep modes and selecting an optimal configuration to achieve a target runtime of at least 30 days.

CO3: Construct a custom PCB prototype for a sensor node, ensuring component placement, trace routing, and thermal design meet industry standards, and validate the board against a design review checklist.
CO4: Configure a secure OTA firmware update pipeline for a microcontroller, implementing cryptographic authentication with TLS and HMAC to verify firmware integrity before installation.
CO5: Develop a real‑time dashboard that visualizes time‑series sensor data, applying UI/UX best practices and data aggregation techniques to clearly demonstrate trend analysis for end‑users.
CO6: Conduct a threat‑analysis assessment on an IoT system, identify privacy risks, and design a compliance plan that aligns with GDPR and ISO/IEC 27001 security controls.

Course Description: This course delves into the foundational principles of Information Theory, exploring concepts such as entropy, mutual information, and their role in quantifying uncertainty. It systematically examines stochastic processes, including Markov chains and random walks, and applies these principles to critical areas like data compression and channel capacity. The curriculum covers the construction of optimal codes and the determination of channel limits. Furthermore, students will synthesize proofs of fundamental theorems and investigate advanced topics like differential entropy and maximum entropy. The course culminates in the ability to analyze communication systems and design robust communication models, preparing students for practical applications in communication theory.
Detailed Syllabus: 1. ENTROPY CONCEPT IN PROBABILITY THEORY: Entropy of Finite Schemes, Joint Entropy and Conditional Entropy, Relative Entropy and Mutual Information, Chain Rules, The Uniqueness Theorem, Jensen's Inequality, Log Sum Inequality, Data Processing Inequalities, Sufficient Statistics, Fano's Inequality.
2. PROBABILITY MEASURE AND ASYMPTOTIC EQUIPARTION PROPERTY: Probability as a measure, Law of Large Number, Asymptotic Equipartition Theorem (AEP), Data Compression, Typical Sets.
3. ENTROPY RATES OF A STOCHASTIC PROCESS: Entropy of Markov Chains, Entropy Rate, Entropy Rate of a random walk on a weighted graph, Hidden Markov Models, Fundamental Theorems.
4. DATA COMPRESSION: Kraft Inequality, Optimal Codes, Bound on the optimal code length, Kraft inequality for Uniquely Decodable Codes, Huffman Codes, Optimality of Huffman code.

5. CHANNEL CAPACITY: Examples of Channel Capacity, Symmetric Channels, Properties of Channel Capacity, Joint Typical Sequence, Channel Coding theorem, Zero Error Codes, Fano's Inequality, Feedback Capacity.

6. DIFFERENTIAL ENTROPY MAXIMUM ENTROPY AND SPECTRAL ESTIMATION: Definition, AEP for Continuous Random Variable, Relation of Differential Entropy to Discrete Entropy, Joint and Conditional Entropy, Relative Entropy and Mutual Information, Maximum Entropy distributions, Anomalous Maximum Entropy Problem, Spectrum Estimation
Generated_LOs: CO1: Analyze Shannon entropy, joint entropy, and mutual information for specified discrete probability mass functions, and interpret the quantified uncertainty implications.
CO2: Construct optimal prefix codes using Huffman encoding for given source distributions, verify compliance with the Kraft inequality, and calculate the average code length expected.

CO3: Design a typical-set-based compression scheme for a memoryless source, empirically validate the asymptotic equipartition property, and measure compression efficiency relative to theoretical limits.
CO4: Prove and apply Fano's inequality and the channel coding theorem to compute attainable error probabilities for binary symmetric channels, including scenarios with feedback.

CO5: Derive and compute differential entropy for transformed continuous random variables, and apply the maximum entropy principle to determine the appropriate distribution family given moment constraints.

CO6: Implement a first-order Markov chain simulation, estimate its entropy rate from sample paths, and compare the empirical estimate with the theoretical entropy rate derived from the stationary distribution.

CO7: Evaluate periodogram-based spectral estimation for stationary stochastic processes, quantifying bias and variance trade-offs, and interpret the implications for underlying process characterization.

Course Description: This course provides a comprehensive exploration of environmental science and technology, addressing pressing global challenges such as climate change, degradation, and resource management. It synthesizes foundational environmental issues with advanced technological applications, including geospatial analysis, carbon sequestration methods, and green IT solutions. The curriculum also delves into crucial assessment frameworks like Environmental Impact Assessment and green accounting principles. Students will gain the capacity to evaluate diverse environmental technologies, integrate digital solutions for problem-solving, and develop a robust understanding of environmental ethics and legislative frameworks, fostering informed and responsible environmental stewardship.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit-1: Basics of Environmental Science & Technology: Comprehend environment and its issues, Environmental problems and challenges, Environmental Events.
Unit-2: Earth components; Climate Change: Climate system, Climate feedback loops, Climate Models, Climate impact on environment; Global Catastrophes, unexpected climate changes.
Unit-3: Role of geospatial technology in assessing environmental degradation.
Unit-4: Carbon sequestration methods - vegetation, ocean and geological sequestration, IPCC, Clean Development Mechanisms, CO2, Environmental Stress - Mitigation: Impact on vegetation.
Unit-5: Environmental Impact Assessment: Procedure, regulations and case studies.
Unit-6: Environment and Information technology: green computation, green energy, Green Engineering and technology, e-waste-disposal mechanism - impact on health.
Unit-7: Green accounting- Evolution of process, history, case studies, Accounting of goods and Services, Sustainability concepts.
Unit-8: Environmental movements.
Unit-9: Environmental Legislation & Impact Assessment: Important legislations related to Environment; Environmental Auditing; Environmental Ethics
Generated_LOs: CO1: Analyze climate model outputs using GIS to quantify atmospheric CO₂ flux and assess implications for regional mitigation strategies
CO2: Design a green IT framework that implements energy-efficient server configurations, reducing server energy consumption by at least 30% in a simulated data center
CO3: Evaluate a proposed carbon sequestration project by applying IPCC carbon accounting methodology, calculating net CO₂ removal and lifecycle emissions

CO4: Construct a complete Environmental Impact Assessment report for a proposed mining operation, including methodology, stakeholder engagement, mitigation measures, and alignment with national legislation
CO5: Implement a digital green accounting system that classifies and tracks the carbon footprints of a manufacturing supply chain using input–output analysis
CO6: Demonstrate ethical decision-making for e‑waste disposal by applying environmental ethics frameworks and relevant legislation to a real-world scenario
CO7: Integrate geospatial analytic tools such as ArcGIS and remote sensing to map land degradation hotspots and propose data-driven restoration interventions

Course Title: Fairness, Privacy and Ethics in Al
Course Description: This course critically examines fairness, privacy, and ethical considerations in AI systems. Students will investigate sources of algorithmic bias, exploring diverse notions of individual fairness (e.g., envy-freeness) and group fairness (e.g., equalized odds). The curriculum synthesizes algorithms to mitigate discrimination, addressing the complexities of achieving equitable AI. Additionally, it tackles data privacy challenges, covering potential attacks on machine learning models. Practical techniques like differential privacy (e.g., Laplace, Gaussian mechanisms) are applied to ensure robust individual privacy, fostering transparency and responsible AI development.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Bias in the data, causality, Individual fairness vs group fairness.
Unit 2: Individual fairness: envy freeness, max-min share, proportionality. Algorithms to achieve them such as round robin, cycle elimination, etc.
Unit 3: Impossibility of fair classifier with perfect calibration.

Unit 4: Group fairness (equalized odds, disparate impact, accuracy parity, predictive parity). Different preprocessing, post processing techniques and over all approach to build Al to mitigate discrimination.
Unit 5: Differential Privacy (DP), Need for newer privacy measures, especially when federated learning is on rise. Possible attacks even data is anonymized.
Unit 6: Techniques such as Laplace mechanism, gaussian mechanism, local DP, Bayesian DP
Generated_LOs: CO1: Analyze sources of algorithmic bias in training corpora using statistical and causal metrics to quantify disparate impact within a given dataset.
CO2: Design and implement individual fairness enforcement algorithms (e.g., envy-freeness, max‑min share) using round‑robin and cycle‑elimination techniques on benchmark fairness datasets.
CO3: Evaluate the trade‑offs between perfect calibration and equalized odds by constructing simulated classifiers and comparing ROC curves and calibration plots.

CO4: Construct a mitigation pipeline that applies preprocessing, in‑processing, and post‑processing techniques to reduce disparate impact, implementing standard fairness metrics (equalized odds, predictive parity) in Python with scikit‑learn.

CO5: Apply differential privacy mechanisms—Laplace, Gaussian, and local DP—to machine learning model training, ensuring ε‑differential privacy guarantees while maintaining ≥80% model utility on a protected dataset.

CO6: Demonstrate susceptibility of anonymized datasets to inference attacks by designing a re‑identification attack pipeline and measuring re‑identification accuracy before and after applying differential privacy controls.

CO7: Develop a report that compares the effectiveness of traditional DP with Bayesian DP in protecting user privacy in federated learning settings, including empirical evaluation of attack resilience.

Course Description: This course offers a foundational understanding of the Finite Element Method (FEM), beginning with core principles and approximate solution techniques for boundary value problems. It systematically covers the formulation and application of FEM to one-dimensional scenarios, including structural elements like bars, beams, and trusses. The curriculum advances to two-dimensional problems, exploring triangular, quadrilateral, and isoparametric elements, coupled with essential numerical integration methods. Students will gain proficiency in formulating, solving, and analyzing complex structural and elasticity problems using finite element techniques.
Detailed Syllabus: Module 1: Introduction to finite element method (FEM): Need for FEM, General finite element solution procedure, Boundary value problems: types of boundary conditions, Approximate solution to boundary value problems: Method of weighted residuals.

Module 2: General one-dimensional (1D) boundary value problem and its applications: Axial deformation of bars: Approximate solution using Rayleigh-Ritz method, Galerkin method, Axial Spring element. Applications: One-dimensional heat flow, Column buckling. Higher order elements for 1D problems.

Module 3: Beams, Frames and Trusses: Beam bending-governing differential equation, Two node beam element, Analysis of structural frames-Plane frame element, space frame element, Introduction to truss analysis.

Module 4: 2D boundary value problems: triangular elements, isoparametric quadrilateral elements, Isoparametric mapping for quadrilateral elements, Numerical integration for quadrilateral elements, Four node quadrilateral element for 2D BVP, Eight node serendipity element. Isoparametric triangular elements.

Module 5: Applications based on general 2D boundary value problem: Torsion of prismatic bars. 2D elasticity-Governing differential equations, Constant strain triangular element, Four node quadrilateral element, Eight node isoparametric element. Constitutive equations, governing differential equations, stress equilibrium equations, finite element equations for plane stress and plane strain conditions.

Module 6: Numerical integration-Newton-Cotes rules, Trapezium rule, Simpson's rule, Error term, Gauss-Legendre rules, Gauss-Leguerre rule, Numerical integration for quadrilateral elements, Numerical integration for triangular elements
Generated_LOs: CO1: Design a one‑dimensional finite element model of an axially loaded bar using Galerkin weighting to compute nodal displacements and axial stresses.

CO2: Apply the Rayleigh–Ritz and Galerkin methods to approximate temperature distribution in a steady‑state one‑dimensional heat flow problem and compare the numerical results with analytical solutions.

CO3: Construct and solve a two‑dimensional finite element formulation for plane stress using a four‑node isoparametric quadrilateral element, implementing Gauss‑Legendre numerical integration to evaluate the element stiffness matrix.
CO4: Evaluate convergence behavior of higher‑order 1D beam elements by implementing quartic shape functions, computing error norms against a refined mesh solution, and reporting trends in accuracy.

CO5: Demonstrate the use of Newton‑Cotes and Gauss‑Legendre integration rules to accurately compute the stiffness matrix of an eight‑node serendipity quadrilateral element for a 2D elasticity problem.

CO6: Analyze the influence of element distortion on solution accuracy by modeling a triangular element with varying node positions, computing stress distributions, and interpreting results within finite element theory.

Course Title: Foundations for Signal Processing and Communication
Course Description: This course establishes a rigorous mathematical foundation for understanding and designing signal processing and communication systems. It systematically explores probability theory, random variables, and stochastic processes, applying these to analyze communication channels and noise. Further, it delves into abstract algebra and linear algebra, covering vector spaces, linear transformations, Fourier analysis, and their applications in signal representation and system analysis. Students will develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills, enabling them to apply these mathematical tools to complex problems and conduct foundational research in communication and signal processing.
Detailed Syllabus: Module 1: Rigorous Math Part: Probability Axioms, Random Variables and their distributions (CDF, PDF, PMF), Some Important Distributions, Joint and Conditional Distributions, Distributions of functions of Random Variables, Expectation of RVs and their functions; SPCOM Part: Random quantities in SPCOM, Notion of Communication Channel, Hypothesis testing, Simple Detection and Estimation problems in Signal Engineering.

Module 2: Rigorous Math Part: Concentration inequalities (Markov, Chebyshev, Chernoff), Central Limit Theorem, Mean vector and covariance matrix, Joint Gaussian Distribution, Random Processes; SPCOM Part: Discrete Memoryless Channels and Notion of Channel Capacity, Gaussian Noise, Wireless Channel.

Module 3: Sets with structure; Rigorous Math Part: Groups, Rings, Fields, Vector spaces, Inner Product on Vector Spaces; SPCOM part: The Vector Space of Finite Energy Continuous Signals, Vector Space of Sampled Signals, Vector Space of discrete-time quantized signals, Distinguishing features of Digital Signal Processing and Communication.

Module 4: Rigorous Math part: Linear Independence/dependence, Span, Column space and row space of matrices, Basis and Dimension of subspaces, Basis Extension Theorem, Rank of a matrix, Change of Basis; SPCOM part: Fourier Series of L_2 signals as representation of signals using Fourier basis, Finite dimensionality of bounded-time, bounded-bandwidth L_2 signals, standard basis for Discrete-time signals, Standard Basis for Finite-field Signals, Discrete Fourier Transform as Change of Basis.

Module 5: Rigorous Math Part: Linear Transformations between vector spaces and their associated Matrices, Eigen Values and Vectors, Triangularization, Diagonalization, SVD; SPCOM part: Continuous-time and Discrete-Time LTI systems and their Transfer Functions, Role of linear transformations in coding theory for forward-error correction, Do Estimation, MIMO Wireless Communication
Generated_LOs: CO1: Analyze probability density functions, cumulative distribution functions, and expected value calculations of specified random variables and use Markov and Chebyshev inequalities to bound error probabilities in a binary communication channel corrupted by Gaussian noise.
CO2: Design a discrete memoryless channel model, calculate its Shannon capacity analytically, and validate the result through Monte‑Carlo simulation of symbol transmission over the channel.

CO3: Construct a complete orthonormal basis for the space of finite‑energy continuous signals on a finite interval and employ it to represent a given signal via Fourier series, explicitly computing coefficients and demonstrating convergence in the L2 norm.

CO4: Demonstrate matrix diagonalization, eigenvalue decomposition, and singular value decomposition for a linear transformation modeling a MIMO communication channel; compute singular values and interpret them as channel gains and condition number.

CO5: Implement the discrete Fourier transform algorithm on a sampled signal, analyze its computational complexity, and compare the frequency spectrum obtained with the continuous Fourier transform of the underlying continuous‑time signal.

CO6: Evaluate the performance of a linear block error‑correcting code over a finite field by constructing generator and parity‑check matrices, encoding transmitted data, adding white Gaussian noise, and computing bit‑error‑rate curves across varying signal‑to‑noise ratios.

CO7: Apply Chernoff bound concentration inequalities to a hypothesis testing scenario in signal detection, derive explicit probability bounds on false alarm and miss detection rates, and verify the bounds against simulated data.

Course Description: This course delves into the foundational theories and practices of gender studies, examining its multifaceted construction within socio-cultural contexts. Students will analyze core concepts such as gender, sex, and diverse sexualities, alongside frameworks of power, ideology, patriarchy, and intersectionality. The curriculum traces the evolution of feminist movements and critically examines how gender is established, represented, and potentially disrupted through literary works and popular cinema. Ultimately, the course fosters a critical understanding of gender relations, empowering students to challenge preconceived notions and engage informedly with societal roles and cultural formations.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Core concepts and terms: Differences between terms like Gender, Sex, Normative and Non-normative sexuality, Trans-bodies.
Unit 2: Power, Ideology and Intersectionality's: Concepts of Power, Ideology, Patriarchy, and Privilege. What are intersectionality's, and why is it important to study them when we study gender?
Unit 3: Feminist Movements: Rights struggles, Gains and losses, women in the workplace, Women in India.
Unit 4: Representation of Gender: Who writes women? Short Stories on, about, and by women.
Unit 5: Popular representations of women in cinema. How does popular visual culture shape gender politics?
Generated_LOs: CO1: Analyze the conceptual distinctions among gender, sex, normative and non-normative sexuality, and trans bodies in at least two scholarly sources, and produce a comparative matrix.
CO2: Evaluate how power, ideology, patriarchy, and privilege interact within an intersectional framework by applying critical analysis to a contemporary social issue on campus.
CO3: Construct a critique of feminist movements' gains and losses, focusing on Women in India, by synthesizing at least three primary documents and providing a contextual assessment.
CO4: Design a short story analytical framework that identifies patriarchal narratives and feminist subtext, and apply it to two works by women writers studied in the unit.
CO5: Create a visual media critique of a popular film depicting women, mapping gender representations to ideological constructs, and presenting findings in a multimedia presentation.
CO6: Develop a community engagement proposal that utilizes theory learned about gender relations to address a specific gender-based conflict, including measurable outcome indicators.

Course Title: Geospatial Technology for Disaster Risk Modelling
Course Description: This course provides a comprehensive exploration of geospatial technology for disaster risk modelling. It integrates principles of remote sensing and GIS to address disaster risk reduction and management across diverse contexts. Students will analyze specific disaster phenomena, including floods, droughts, forest fires, and landslides, focusing on their monitoring, assessment, and vulnerability modelling through space-based data. The curriculum emphasizes practical skills in processing remotely sensed data, understanding existing early warning systems, and identifying applications of AI/ML. Graduates will be equipped to contribute to evidence-based decision support for disaster management and resilience building.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit-1: Introduction to disasters overview, perspectives, national/international frameworks, conceptual approach to disaster risk reduction and management using geospatial technology.
Unit-2: Flood risk and impact; Introduction to floods; Remote sensing of floods; Flood risk and vulnerability modelling and assessment.
Unit-3: Drought; Introduction to drought; Role of remote sensing in drought monitoring; Drought assessment and modelling.

Unit-4: Forest fires & open biomass burning; Introduction to fires; Remote sensing of fires; Introduction to 'fire danger rating' (early warning system) modelling; Artificial Intelligence for fire monitoring and management.

Unit-5: Landslides; Introduction to landslides; Remote sensing applications for Identification of landslide, classification and post-event analysis; Monitoring of landslides; Landslide susceptibility and hazard assessment
Generated_LOs: CO1: Analyze multi-temporal Landsat imagery to delineate flood extent and quantify inundation depth for a case study watershed, producing an urban inundation map with accuracy assessed against ground truth data.

CO2: Design and implement a GIS-based drought monitoring paradigm that integrates NDVI, precipitation, and temperature time series, generating drought severity maps and assessing spatial patterns using TOPSIS technique.
CO3: Develop a machine-learning model that predicts fire danger rating using MODIS thermal anomaly data and environmental covariates, evaluating model performance with RMSE and AUC.

CO4: Construct a landslide susceptibility map for a mountainous region using Sentinel-2 derived slope, aspect, soil moisture, and rainfall data, applying logistic regression and MoRAMC procedure, and validate with post-event landslide inventory.

CO5: Evaluate the effectiveness of an existing early warning system by analyzing spatial coverage, temporal resolution, and decision-support output against actual disaster events, presenting findings in a concise report.

CO6: Apply remote sensing classification techniques (e.g., Random Forest) to detect new vegetation loss from forest fires, producing asset maps for forest management and communicating uncertainty ranges.

CO7: Demonstrate the integration of spatial analysis outputs into a stakeholder-friendly dashboard using ArcGIS Pro and Python, enabling real-time decision support during an emergency scenario simulation.

Course Description: This course explores the foundational principles of Human-Computer Interaction (HCI), examining its profound influence on the user experience of digital products. It delves into human-machine systems, cognitive models, and the Human-Action Cycle, integrating key UX and UI design principles, including Gestalt theory, information architecture, and prototyping. Emphasizing a user-centered approach, the curriculum covers persona development, task analysis, and design workflows. Students will gain the ability to create useful and intuitive digital solutions, alongside competently planning, executing, and reporting on comprehensive usability testing to refine product designs.
Detailed Syllabus: UNIT 1. Introduction to Human-Computer Interaction: Introduction to HCI?; History of HCI; How Human interact with outside world?; Human Conceptual/Mental models; Conflict between Mental Models and Design Models.
UNIT 2. UNDERSTANDING Human-Machine System: Understanding Human-Machine System; Human-Action Cycle (HAC); 7stagesofHuman-action cycle; User Experience.

UNIT 3. Art and Science of User Experience and UI Design: Aaention and Memory; Gestalt theory and principles; UI Elements including colour and interaction model; Information and Interaction Design principles.

UNIT 4. User-Centered approach to the Solware Design: Perceived Usefulness and perceived Ease of Use; Understanding User Persona; Why user person is important; Use cases, User stories; Task Flows & Task Analysis; Human-centeredsoRware Design Workflow.
UNIT 5. User Experience and UI Design: Information Architecture; Wireframes and Storyboards; Low and High-Fidelity prototypes.

UNIT 6. Usability Engineering and Testing: What is Usability, usability requirements and how to measure it?; Heuristics evaluation; Usability Test planning and conducting usability test; Usability matrix and test reporting.
UNIT 7. Usability Engineering and Testing: Short term project; Project completion, documentation and submission
Generated_LOs: CO1: Analyze user mental models and design models for a given mobile application, identify at least three conflicts between user expectations and interface behavior, and recommend design adjustments; deliverable: a 2-page analysis report.

CO2: Apply Gestalt principles to design a low-fidelity wireframe of a web dashboard, ensuring that each element follows at least two Gestalt rules, and present the wireframe in a 4-slide presentation.
CO3: Create a detailed user persona and accompanying task flow diagram using task analysis methods for a specified digital product, resulting in a 5-page persona profile and a 3-step flowchart.

CO4: Conduct a heuristic evaluation of a prototype UI, scoring each of Nielsen’s 10 heuristics on a 5-point Likert scale, and compile a usability matrix summarizing strengths and weaknesses in a 1-page report.

CO5: Develop a high-fidelity interactive prototype in Figma that incorporates the information architecture created in CO3, run a usability test with at least 4 participants, and produce a 2-page test report with recommendations.

CO6: Synthesize insights from user testing, heuristic evaluation, and design iterations to write a comprehensive project documentation report, including usability analysis, design rationale, and future improvement plan; deliver as a 10-page PDF.

Course Description: The Human Sciences Lab offers an intensive exploration into the application of computational methods for social science research. Students will engage with diverse datasets, from textual corpora like social media and news articles to electoral statistics, employing techniques such as Bag of Words and statistical correlation. This involves hands-on practice in data acquisition, interpretation, and critical analysis. The course develops proficiency in leveraging computational tools while fostering the critical application of social theory to interpret findings, enabling students to discern both the potential and inherent limitations of these methodologies.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Bag of Words exercise, followed by analysis of the results.
Unit 2: Identification and interpretation of correlations in social data. Statistical analysis, followed by study of the historical/sociological/political context.
Unit 3: Crawling of tweets, followed by an analysis of the results from a social science perspective.
Unit 4: Scraping of newspaper articles, followed by an analysis of the results from a social science perspective.
Unit 5: Working with Political Data: Extracting electoral data from various sites, followed by an analysis of the results from a social science perspective
Generated_LOs: CO1: Implement a Bag of Words model using scikit‑learn on the provided corpus and evaluate term frequency distributions to identify key semantic themes.

CO2: Extract tweet data with Tweepy, preprocess the text, and calculate statistical correlations between sentiment scores and user engagement metrics, documenting the workflow in a reproducible Jupyter Notebook.
CO3: Scrape articles from two major news outlets using Scrapy, clean the HTML content, and compute lexical diversity metrics, comparing results across outlets in a data visualisation.

CO4: Retrieve electoral data from multiple official websites using Selenium, aggregate the datasets, and conduct correlation analysis between voter turnout and campaign spend, visualising findings with matplotlib.
CO5: Evaluate the ethical implications of web scraping and data crawling practices in a written report, applying social science theories to assess potential biases and limitations.

CO6: Construct a critical discussion that links computational findings to sociopolitical context, and deliver an oral presentation articulating both the strengths and limitations of the methods employed.

Course Description: This course delves into hydrological modeling, emphasizing the integration of computational techniques for advanced water resource management. It covers foundational principles, including fluid mechanics, hydrology, statistical analysis, and optimization methods. The curriculum then progresses to complex systems, exploring river basin and urban hydrology, water quality modeling, and management strategies for floods, droughts, and climate change impacts. Students will gain practical experience with open-source public domain software and decision support systems. The course culminates in developing computational algorithms and tools to analyze, predict, and formulate optimal, real-time solutions for diverse water-related challenges.
Detailed Syllabus: Introduction: fundamentals of fluid mechanics and open channel flows; hydrology, rainfall and runoff processes and hydro-climatology, statistical analysis, optimization methods. Water Resources Systems: river basin and urban hydrology, river water quality modelling, flood and drought management, irrigation and reservoir operation and climate change. Technologies and Software: Open-source public domain software based on Microsoft Windows environment: US Environmental Protection Agency's Qual2k; MATLAB Tools: Air2stream; Windows based decision support systems. Development and Application of Software: Real-world applications at various scales for water resources management
Generated_LOs: CO1: Analyze the application of continuity and momentum equations within QUAL2K to simulate open‑channel flood routing for a specified 10‑km reach by the semester’s end
CO2: Design a Monte Carlo‑based rainfall‑runoff model in MATLAB that produces 95% confidence intervals for peak discharge of a small watershed by the course’s conclusion

CO3: Implement a genetic‑algorithm optimization routine in Air2stream to determine reservoir release schedules that minimize flood risk while maintaining prescribed water‑quality criteria by semester completion

CO4: Evaluate the performance of a QUAL2K water‑quality simulation against observed stream‑reach concentration data by calculating bias, RMSE, and Nash‑Sutcliffe efficiency for a 12‑month trial period

CO5: Develop a web‑based decision support interface (HTML/JavaScript + Python backend) that ingests real‑time rainfall forecasts, applies the calibrated HYDROL model, and delivers real‑time flood advisories for an urban catchment before final project submission

CO6: Construct an automated MATLAB reporting workflow that processes daily runoff data, generates monthly trend charts, and outputs a standardized PDF report for water‑resource managers by the end of the course

Course Description: This course delves into the fundamental principles and advanced techniques of Information Retrieval (IR) and Extraction. It covers various IR models, evaluation methodologies, and the unique challenges of Web Information Retrieval, including crawling strategies. Students will explore the integration of Natural Language Processing and Machine Learning approaches to enhance retrieval efficacy and develop robust information extraction systems. Practical application is emphasized, enabling students to design algorithms, architect comprehensive IR systems for the web, and effectively process unstructured and noisy data from diverse repositories.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Introduction to Information retrieval, Information Extraction and Information Access systems.
Unit 2: Information Retrieval Models and Evaluation of IR systems.
Unit 3: Web Information Retrieval.
Unit 4: Natural Language Processing in IR.
Unit 5: Machine Learning in Information Retrieval Systems.
Unit 6: Information Extraction.
Unit 7: IR Applications
Generated_LOs: CO1: Analyze the effectiveness of Boolean, vector-space, and probabilistic IR models by computing precision, recall, MAP, and NDCG on the TREC Core Collection and interpreting the results to identify model suitability for different query types.

CO2: Design and implement a domain‑specific web crawler in Python using Scrapy that honors robots.txt, handles JavaScript‑rendered pages with Selenium, and stores crawled URLs and page contents in a normalized SQLite database.

CO3: Evaluate web IR challenges such as duplicate detection, flash news retrieval, and ranking decay by applying OKAPI BM25, learning‑to‑rank algorithms, and runtime profiling, then produce a comparative report of performance trade‑offs.

CO4: Integrate natural language processing techniques—including tokenization, stop‑word removal, stemming, syntactic parsing, and named entity recognition—into an IR pipeline to perform query expansion and relevance feedback, and assess the impact on retrieval metrics.

CO5: Design and implement a machine‑learning ranking model using BERT‑based embeddings and gradient‑boosted trees, fine‑tune it on a labeled query–document dataset, and evaluate its performance against BM25 baselines using precision@10, MAP, and NDCG.

CO6: Construct and validate an information‑extraction pipeline that employs spaCy rule‑based patterns and conditional random fields to extract person, organization, and location entities from noisy web text, then calculate precision, recall, and F1‑score on a manually annotated test set.

CO7: Design a full IR system architecture for an e‑commerce product catalog, incorporating data ingestion, distributed indexing with Elasticsearch, a RESTful query API, and a user interface built with React, then document a Docker‑based deployment plan and demonstrate end‑to‑end retrieval and extraction functionality.

Course Description: This course explores Information Theory, foundational for data compression and reliable communication. It covers essential concepts like entropy, mutual information, and the Asymptotic Equipartition Property, applying them to source coding techniques such as Huffman and Lempel-Ziv. The curriculum advances to channel capacity, Shannon's coding theorems, and modern codes like Polar Codes. Students will analyze communication channels and employ information-theoretic arguments for converse proofs in areas including private information retrieval and data exchange. This equips them to analyze system capacities, design efficient compression, and construct rigorous proofs for advanced communication and data challenges.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Random Variables as Signals at Source and Receivers, Source Coding Entropy and its properties, Relative entropy, Mutual information, Huffman codes and optimality, Asymptotic Equipartition Property and Typical set-based source coding.

Unit 2: Channel coding - Channel capacity motivation and definition, Discrete memoryless channel, Channel coding theorem for DMC- achievability and converse, Differential Entropy, Guassian Channel Capacity.
Unit 3: Polar Codes as Efficient Capacity Achieving Codes for DMCS.
Unit 4: Converse Results using Information Theoretic Arguments: Private Information Retrieval, Data Exchange between Nodes, DNA Storage, Adversarial Channels
Generated_LOs: CO1: Analyze the entropy and mutual information of discrete source models to compute theoretical coding bounds and verify the optimality of Huffman codes for given empirical probability distributions.
CO2: Design and implement Lempel-Ziv compression algorithms, evaluating compression efficiency against theoretical entropy limits for synthetic and real-world data sets.

CO3: Evaluate the capacity of discrete memoryless and Gaussian channels by deriving mutual information expressions and demonstrating achievability through simulation of decoding error probabilities versus transmission rates.

CO4: Construct polar code ensembles that achieve capacity for binary-symmetric discrete memoryless channels, and validate performance via simulation of bit-error rates as the operating rate approaches channel capacity.

CO5: Develop rigorous converse proofs using information-theoretic inequalities for private information retrieval protocols, and assess the near-optimality of proposed protocols against derived bounds.
CO6: Analyze DNA storage encoding schemes by applying channel capacity concepts to biochemical error models, designing error-correcting codes that satisfy specified storage density constraints.

Course Description: This course provides a foundational introduction to Cognitive Science, an interdisciplinary field investigating the nature of mind and intelligence. Students will explore its historical evolution, empirical methodologies, and core domains including sensation, perception, attention, memory, language, learning, and knowledge representation. The curriculum also delves into complex topics like consciousness and special areas bridging neuroscience, philosophy, and artificial intelligence. Emphasizing critical analysis, the course equips students to evaluate research design, identify communication flaws in scientific findings, and articulate well-informed perspectives on ongoing scientific debates.
Detailed Syllabus: Introduction; Evolution of Cognitive Science; A free-form discussion on consciousness; Empirical approaches in cognitive science; Brain: Organization; Intro to sensation and perception; Sensory systems; Perception and Perceptual Learning, Cross-modal interactions; Vision; Attention; Learning; Development; Memory; Language and Cognition; Knowledge Representation; Special topics: e.g. Music, mind, and technology; Several debate sessions with student debate teams
Generated_LOs: CO1: Analyze empirical research papers in cognitive science to identify study design, statistical tests, and potential biases, supporting critique with evidence.
CO2: Evaluate the reliability and validity of sensory perception experiments using quantitative measures such as signal detection theory and response bias calculations.
CO3: Design a basic laboratory experiment to investigate attentional modulation, detailing hypothesis, operational definitions, sampling, and data analysis plan.
CO4: Compare and contrast predominant theories of memory consolidation (e.g., systems consolidation vs. synaptic consolidation) through structured argumentation and evidence mapping.
CO5: Construct a functional model of language processing that integrates linguistic, cognitive, and neural components, illustrating how each domain interacts during real-time comprehension.
CO6: Critique a contemporary debate on consciousness by articulating a coherent position, presenting counterarguments, and proposing empirical methods to test the contested claim.

Course Description: This course provides a comprehensive introduction to the scientific study of psychology, exploring its historical foundations and diverse methodologies. It delves into core domains such as neuroscience, emotion, personality, social cognition, learning, and life-span development. The curriculum also addresses psychological health and intervention strategies. Students will analyze psychological phenomena through various perspectives, understand research ethics, and apply evidence-based knowledge to develop critical thinking and foster personal and professional effectiveness.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Introduction - Psychology as a Science, Goals of Psychology, History of Psychology.
Unit 2: Methods - Research methods for psychological observations.
Unit 3: Health & Psychology - Psychological health and disorders, Neuroscience and behaviour, Emotion.
Unit 4: Social & Personality - Social, Psychological interventions and treatments, Personality.
Unit 5: Cognitive - Attention, Gender, Memory.
Unit 6: Learning & Development - Learning, Perception, Life-span development, Intelligence

CO3: Design a behavior change intervention plan for treating social anxiety disorder that incorporates evidence-based CBT techniques and adheres to APA ethical guidelines.
CO4: Evaluate the neural correlates of reward processing by interpreting fMRI data from a published study and explaining how striatal activation relates to motivation.

Course Description: This course provides a comprehensive introduction to fundamental biological principles, starting with the cellular and chemical foundations of life, including biomolecular structures and functions. It progresses to explore bioenergetics, metabolism, and the physical principles governing cellular processes. The curriculum then delves into genetic foundations, covering DNA, gene expression, replication, and evolutionary mechanisms. Students will also investigate cell signaling, DNA manipulation techniques, and the computational challenges in modern biology, preparing them to analyze complex biological information and apply interdisciplinary approaches.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Cellular foundations: Cell organelles, Membranes and cellular compartments, Tree of life.
Unit 2: Chemical foundations: Biomolecules, Structure and function.
Unit 3: Physical foundations: Bioenergetics, Catalysis, Enzymes, Photosynthesis, Respiration.
Unit 4: How cells obtain energy from the food - metabolism.
Unit 5: Genetic foundations: DNA, Genes, chromosomes, Genomes, Mutations.
Unit 6: Evolutionary foundations, Systematics.
Unit 7: DNA Replication, Repair, and Recombination - an overview.
Unit 8: How Cells Read the Genome: From DNA to Protein.
Unit 9: Control of Gene expression.
Unit 10: Cell Signaling, Cell cycle.
Unit 11: Analyzing and manipulating DNA.
Unit 12: Introduction to sequencing and computational challenges

CO6: Apply next-generation sequencing data analysis to identify single nucleotide variants in a provided genomic dataset, reporting variant frequency, predicted functional impact, and potential clinical relevance

Course Description: This course provides a foundational understanding of economics, exploring its diverse definitions and the historical evolution of major schools of thought, including Neoclassical, Marxist, and Keynesian. Students will delve into core microeconomic principles of decision-making and market structures, alongside macroeconomic theories encompassing aggregate demand, supply, inflation, and fiscal policy. The curriculum also introduces international trade dynamics and exchange rate determination. Emphasizing distinct economic conditions in developing nations, the course explores economics' interdisciplinary connections, preparing students to analyze complex social phenomena and inform relevant policy interventions.
Detailed Syllabus: 1. ‘Ways of doing economics: Different views on scope and definition of economics. Alternative schools of economic thought- Neoclassical, Marxist, Keynesian.
2. Theoretical foundations of microeconomics: Agent based understanding of decision making individuals and firms. Market structure and game theory. Welfare economics, Information economics.

3. Theoretical foundations of macroeconomics: Macroeconomic measurement. Aggregate demand, aggregate supply and determination of output. Inflation and Unemployment, Monetary and Fiscal Policy. Banking and the role of finance in the economy.
4. Introduction to the open economy: Basic trade theory- absolute advantage, comparative advantage, Heckscher-Ohlin Model. Exchange rate determination. External accounts of an economy.
5. Interdisciplinary engagements with economics: Economics and psychology. Economics and computational science, economics and climate science

CO3: Apply the AD‑AS framework to model the effects of a sudden increase in oil prices on output and inflation, derive the new equilibrium conditions, and explain how an expansionary monetary policy would alter the outcome.

CO4: Design a fiscal policy package for a developing country to curb inflation, incorporating at least two tools (e.g., taxes, transfers), run a basic AD‑AS computation to forecast the impact on output and price level, and assess the trade‑off with debt sustainability.

CO5: Compare the Fisher effect and uncovered interest parity in predicting exchange rate movements for a small open economy, construct a table summarizing their assumptions, and evaluate the potential impact of a dollar appreciation on the trade balance.

CO6: Evaluate the application of prospect theory to a household tax‑credit scheme, design an alternative incentive structure that reduces behavioral bias, and model its expected effect on participation rates using available survey data.

Course Description: This course provides a foundational exploration of film studies, introducing core analytical concepts like mise-en-scène, cinematography, editing, sound, and narrative. It delves into fundamental theoretical conversations on medium specificity, realism, and film phenomenology, including historical perspectives such as the Soviet School and digital cinema. The curriculum also examines influential global cinema movements, including German Expressionism, New Wave, and Noir. Students will develop a comprehensive understanding of cinema as a complex artistic medium, industrial practice, and cultural phenomenon, fostering critical interpretation of its role in art and politics.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Basic terms of analysis and interpretation. Misѐ-en-Scѐne, Cinematography, Editing, Sound, Narrative, Genre.
Unit 2: Fundamental conversations on medium specificity, Realism in Cinema, Phenomenology of film, the Soviet School, Digital Cinema.
Unit 3: Introduction to cinema movements. May include – German Expressionism, New Wave/s, Noir, Indian art film movement

Course Description: This course provides a comprehensive introduction to the discipline of History, exploring its foundational concepts and methodologies. Students will investigate how historians understand time and space, critically examining the nature of historical facts and the ongoing debate surrounding objectivity. The curriculum covers major theoretical models of historical interpretation and various analytical methods, including source criticism, inductive/deductive reasoning, and qualitative/quantitative approaches. Additionally, it offers insights into memory studies, heritage, and public history. Through this engagement, students will develop the capacity to analyze historical narratives, evaluate methodologies, assess primary evidence, and formulate a nuanced understanding of the past.
Detailed Syllabus: (1) Historical Time and Space: In this module students will be introduced to how historians have understood the flow of time and periodised time into historical ages.
(2) Historical Fact and Objectivity: This module will define the historical fact, the different interpretations of what a fact is, and the debate among historians relating to historical objectivity.
(3) The Main Theories of History: In this module students will be exposed to the main theoretical models of historical interpretation.

(4) The Main Methods of Historical Analysis: This module will focus on source criticism, the advantages and limitation of the inductive and deductive methods, oral history, qualitative and quantitative methods.
(5) Memory, heritage and public history: This module will provide students brief introductions to the fields of memory studies, heritage studies and public history
Generated_LOs: CO1: Analyze the construction of historical periodization in two contrasting historiographical traditions (e.g., Marxist and Annales schools) and critique their treatment of time and space within a comparative case study.
CO2: Evaluate primary source materials using comparative source criticism to identify bias, authorship, and context, and produce a balanced assessment report.

CO3: Design a research proposal that applies inductive and deductive reasoning to investigate a specific historical question, detailing methodological strategy, sampling plan, and evidential thresholds.
CO4: Apply quantitative methods (e.g., frequency analysis, statistical trend analysis) to a selected set of archival data and interpret the results in terms of historiographical significance.
CO5: Critique the concept of historical objectivity by drafting a reflective essay that compares at least three theoretical interpretations and proposes criteria for evaluating claims of fact.

CO6: Construct a public history project proposal (e.g., museum exhibit or digital archive) that incorporates memory and heritage studies perspectives, and outline appropriate ethical guidelines and community engagement strategies.

Course Description: This course introduces the scientific study of human language, exploring its fundamental and unique characteristics. Students investigate core linguistic levels, including phonetics, phonology, morphology, and syntax, from both synchronic and diachronic perspectives. The curriculum further examines broader areas like sociolinguistics, language acquisition, historical linguistics, writing systems, and the Paninian grammatical tradition. Through theoretical frameworks and practical data analysis, students develop a robust understanding of linguistic analysis, preparing them to explore diverse languages and contribute to text processing applications.
Detailed Syllabus: 1. What is language? Difference between human language and Animal languages. Natural language, Formal language and Artificial language, Characteristic features of human language, what we know about language.
2. Study of Human language – the field of Linguistics.
3. Looking at language from synchronic and diachronic points of view.

4. Areas of Study from structural perspective: a) Syntagmatic and paradigmatic aspects of language structure; b) Levels of structural analysis: Phonetics, Phonology, Morphology, Syntax; c) From evolution perspective: Historical Linguistics; d) From usage perspective: Sociolinguistics; e) From Psychological perspective: Mechanisms of language acquisition; f) Indian Grammatical Tradition: Paninian grammatical model; g) Writing Systems
Generated_LOs: CO1: Analyze phonetic transcriptions from speech recordings to identify and categorize allophonic variations in vowel and consonant inventories of a target language using IPA symbols.
CO2: Evaluate morphological structures by parsing sample words into morpheme units and constructing morphological trees, applying paradigmatic and syntagmatic analysis.
CO3: Compare synchronic and diachronic language change by mapping lexical shifts in an English historical corpus and producing a timeline of semantic divergence.
CO4: Apply sociolinguistic inquiry by designing a small-scale corpus study to measure variation of a grammatical feature across demographic variables, and reporting statistical measures.
CO5: Design a basic Paninian grammatical description for a given Sanskrit sentence, demonstrating application of nine *karaka* roles and sandhi rules.
CO6: Demonstrate the use of a computational linguistic tool (e.g., Praat or Python NLTK) to perform phoneme frequency analysis on a provided dataset, interpreting results in a report.

Course Title: Introduction to Neural and Cognitive Modeling
Course Description: This course introduces the foundational principles and applications of neural and cognitive modeling, exploring how mathematical and computational methods illuminate brain function. Topics range from single-neuron biophysical models (e.g., Hodgkin-Huxley, LIF) and network-level dynamics like population coding and neuroplasticity, to abstract models of higher cognitive functions such as perception, memory, and language, alongside various learning rules. Students will analyze, evaluate, and design computational solutions for neuroscience problems, developing a critical understanding of these models' strengths and limitations in explaining brain, mind, and behavior, fostering functional and practical insights.
Detailed Syllabus: Part I: Single-Neuron Level Models: Introduction to Neuroscience; Passive membrane models, Leaky Integrate and Fire (LIF) models, Hodgkin-Huxley model, Cable models of dendrites, Synapse model, Compartmental models.

Part II: Network Level Models: Neural population codes; information representation; neural encoding and decoding; hierarchy and organization of sensory systems; Spiking Network models of sensory systems; Neuroplasticity and learning.

Part III: Abstract Models: Introduction to Hebbian, Competitive and Error-driven learning rules; Reinforcement learning, Neural Network models of Perception, Attention, Memory, Language and Executive Function
Generated_LOs: CO1: Analyze Hodgkin‑Huxley membrane equations to predict voltage responses under varied ion conductances in simulated synaptic events
CO2: Design and implement a leaky integrate‑and‑fire population network in Python to emulate visual stimulus encoding, validating performance against analytical firing‑rate predictions
CO3: Evaluate spiking neural network stability by computing Lyapunov exponents and firing‑rate variance, reporting robustness to parameter changes in a lab report
CO4: Implement spike‑timing dependent plasticity (STDP) rules within a cortical microcircuit model, demonstrating learned temporal sequences through spike-train analysis
CO5: Construct a recurrent neural network model of working memory with competition-based weight updates, illustrating capacity limits via recall accuracy metrics
CO6: Create a reinforcement learning simulation of a maze‑navigation task using Q‑learning and policy gradients, comparing algorithm convergence speed and success rates in a comparative analysis

Course Description: This course introduces students to the nature and scope of philosophical inquiry as a rational, second-order discipline. It critically examines core epistemological questions concerning knowledge validity and its sources through thinkers like Descartes, Hume, and Kant. Subsequently, the curriculum explores distinct approaches to human existence and consciousness via Existentialism (Nietzsche, Sartre) and Phenomenology (Husserl, Heidegger). The course then delves into Hermeneutics, investigating interpretation and narrative identity. Students will develop sophisticated analytical skills to distinguish objective and subjective knowledge, analyze self-understanding, and critically evaluate diverse perspectives on belief formation.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Nature and the Scope of Philosophy: Philosophy as a Rational Inquiry, Second-order discipline, Phronesis and the Good Life (Aristotle).
Unit 2: Epistemology: Impression and Ideas (David Hume), Cogito Ergo Sum (Descartes), Transcendental Aesthetic and Categories (Kant).
Unit 3: Existentialism: Übermensch and Eternal Recurrence of the Same (Nietzsche), Bad Faith and Authenticity (Sartre).
Unit 4: Phenomenology: Intentionality and Horizon (Edmund Husserl); Ready-to-hand and Disclosure (Martin Heidegger).
Unit 5: Hermeneutics: Hermeneutical Circle (Gadamer); Narrative Identity (Paul Ricouer)
Generated_LOs: CO1: Argue, using evidence from Descartes' Meditations and Kant's Critique, why each theory supports or challenges the notion of foundational certainty, and evaluate their relevance to contemporary epistemological debates in a 2000-word analytical essay.

CO2: Critique Hume's problem of induction and Aristotle's concept of causality by synthesizing their arguments into a structured comparative analysis report, demonstrating at least three points of convergence and divergence.
CO3: Apply Husserl's method of epoché to deconstruct a contemporary philosophical text, producing a 1500-word interpretive analysis that identifies intentional acts and their horizons.
CO4: Utilize Sartre's concept of bad faith to construct a real-world scenario illustrating self-deception, and assess the psychological and ethical implications in a 1200-word reflective essay.

CO5: Analyze Gadamer's hermeneutical circle by mapping the interpretive stages of a selected primary source, and evaluate the impact of pre-judgments on meaning through a creative diagram and accompanying critical commentary.

CO6: Evaluate the coherence between Nietzsche's Übermensch and Heidegger's ready-to-hand by compiling a comparative chart and an argumentative conclusion that argues for or against their compatibility, presenting findings in an oral presentation and written summary.

Course Description: This course introduces students to the fundamental concepts and foundational theories of Political Science. It defines politics, the state, and governmental forms, then delves into core political concepts such as liberty, equality, justice, rights, and democracy. A significant portion examines the structure, functions, and philosophical underpinnings of the Indian Constitution, its democratic institutions (Parliament, Executive, Judiciary), federalism, secularism, and the electoral process. Students will develop a critical understanding of political systems, particularly in India, enabling them to analyze contemporary challenges and formulate policy perspectives for reforms within the Indian political system.
Detailed Syllabus: Module 1: Introduction to various perspectives on how we define politics and its domain; Nature and scope of Political Science as a field of knowledge; Meaning and origin of State: divine theory and social contract theory; Forms and functions of government.

Module 2: Brief introduction to key concepts of Political Science; Liberty: Negative and Positive; Equality: Equality of Opportunity; Justice: Social Justice; Rights: Legal Rights and Human Rights; Democracy: Idea and Practice.

Module 3: Philosophy and features of Indian constitution, Structure and functions of Parliament (Legislature), Prime Minister and his cabinet (Executive), Supreme Court of India (Judiciary); Balance of Power.
Module 4: Structure and functioning of federalism in India; centre-state relations; Meaning and interpretation of secularism in the Indian context; Provisions for unity in diversity.
Module 5: History and Features of Party system in India; National Parties and State Parties; Trends in the Party System; Electoral Process, Election Commission, Contemporary Challenges and Reforms
Generated_LOs: CO1: Analyze the constitutional principles of federalism in India and evaluate their impact on centre-state fiscal relations.
CO2: Construct a comparative matrix of democratic institutions—Parliament, Executive, Judiciary—highlighting checks and balances as defined by the Indian Constitution.
CO3: Evaluate the legal and human rights framework in Sections 14–19 of the Indian Constitution and propose policy reforms to address contemporary challenges.

CO4: Design a mock electoral process for a state assembly election, detailing candidacy criteria, campaign financing rules, and vote counting mechanisms in accordance with Election Commission guidelines.
CO5: Compare the evolution of national and state party systems in India over the past three decades using quantitative metrics such as vote share and seat distribution.
CO6: Construct a policy brief recommending reforms to strengthen secularism in India, citing constitutional provisions, judicial decisions, and sociopolitical data.

Course Description: This course provides a rigorous introduction to Quantum Field Theory, exploring the motivations behind describing nature through quantum fields rather than wave functions. It covers elements of classical field theory, symmetries, and Noether's theorem, then transitions to functional quantization, path integrals, and Feynman diagrams for scalar and Dirac fields. Students will learn the S-matrix formalism, how to calculate scattering cross-sections, and delve into Quantum Electrodynamics (QED). The course aims to equip students with the ability to apply second quantization techniques and calculate transition amplitudes for fundamental physical processes.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Introduction: review of backgrounds, motivations for QFT.
Unit 2: Elements of Classical Field Theory: symmetries and No ether's theorem.
Unit 3: Functional Formalism: path integral formalism, functional quantization, Feynman diagrams, quantization of scalar field, phi-4 theory.
Unit 4: S-matrix: scattering cross-section and decay rates, from Feynman diagrams to S-matrix.
Unit 5: Dirac Field: Dirac equation and its solutions, gamma matrices, quantization, Green's function.
Unit 6 Quantum Electrodynamics (QED): Feynman rules for QED, cross-section of simple QED processes.
Unit 7 Introduction to Renormalization
Generated_LOs: CO1: Analyze classical field Lagrangians and deduce Noether currents for specified continuous symmetries
CO2: Quantize scalar fields using the path integral formalism and construct the corresponding Feynman rules
CO3: Compute tree-level scattering amplitudes in φ∞ theory via Feynman diagrams and evaluate the resulting differential cross‑sections
CO4: Derive the free Dirac equation, solve for plane‑wave spinor solutions, and construct the associated creation and annihilation operators
CO5: Apply QED Feynman rules to calculate the leading‑order Bhabha scattering cross‑section and compare it with experimental data
CO6: Critically assess UV divergences in one‑loop QED diagrams, introduce dimensional regularization, and outline the renormalization procedure to obtain finite physical predictions

Course Description: This course provides a foundational understanding of remote sensing, focusing on the acquisition and analysis of Earth observation data. Students will explore the physics of electromagnetic radiation and its interaction with Earth materials, critical for understanding optical remote sensing processes. The curriculum covers data acquisition, sensor characteristics, pre-processing, and image enhancement. Emphasis is placed on both conventional and advanced computational methods for information extraction, including multispectral and object-based classifications. The course concludes by discussing diverse applications in environmental monitoring, urban planning, and agriculture, alongside an introduction to emerging technologies like drones and radar, preparing students to extract and interpret spatial information effectively.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit-1: Introduction to Remote sensing: What is remote sensing? Earth Observation Satellites and Platforms.
Unit-2: Physics of Electro Magnetic Radiation (EMR) Radiation laws applicable to remote sensing: EMR interaction with Atmosphere and Earth materials.
Unit-3: Data acquisition and image characteristics, Image pre-processing, Image Enhancement.
Unit-4: Information extraction- Multispectral classification – Visual Interpretation- Digital classification. Object based image classification, Stereo Imagery.
Unit-5: Major applications in Vegetation /wildlife; Hydrology/Agriculture, Disaster management.
Unit-6: Overview of Advanced topics: Drone, Hyperspectral and thermal, Microwave/Radar

CO2: Evaluate atmospheric correction algorithms (e.g., Dark Object Subtraction, 6S) on raw satellite imagery and quantify improvements in surface reflectance accuracy
CO3: Design and implement an object‑based image analysis workflow using open‑source software (e.g., QGIS, Orfeo Toolbox) to classify urban land cover with ≥80% accuracy
CO4: Construct a stereo‑photogrammetry model from UAV nadir imagery to generate a digital elevation model and calculate terrain metrics (e.g., slope, aspect) for flood risk assessment

CO6: Demonstrate end‑to‑end remote sensing data processing pipeline—from data acquisition, preprocessing, feature extraction to classification—for an agricultural crop‑health study, documenting each step and evaluating classification performance

Course Description: This workshop introduces the fundamental principles and practical applications of Internet of Things (IoT) systems, with a focus on structural engineering contexts. It covers essential electrical circuit analysis, embedded system components like microcontrollers, sensors, and actuators. Participants will learn C programming for Arduino and ESP32 platforms, exploring hardware interfacing, communication protocols, and advanced peripherals. The curriculum extends to IoT networking, cloud computing, data analysis, interoperability standards, and security considerations. Upon completion, learners will be equipped to design, develop, and implement robust IoT-based solutions for complex real-world problems, from conceptualization to visualization.
Detailed Syllabus: 1. Basic properties of electricity and electrical circuits - DC, Voltage, Current, Power, Energy, Resistance, Ohm’s Law, Circuit Diagrams.
2. Kirchoff’s voltage and current laws, series and parallel resistance, Voltage and Current divider.
3. Online Simulations using TinkerCAD.
4. Basic Circuits, Mesh analysis, Node analysis.
5. What is IoT, Embedded Systems, Components of Embedded Systems, Microcontrollers, Sensors and Actuators, Analog/Digital conversion, Internet structure, Protocols, TCP/IP.
6. Arduino Environment, C Programming, Arduino programming and debugging, URAT Protocol.
7. Interfacing with Arduino, Pulse Width Modulation, Arduino Libraries, I2C communication, Arduino Shields.
8. Peripherals: RTC, ADC channels, resolution, onboard memory, power, external/internal watchdog.
9. Communications and Networking in IoT.
10. Cloud Computing and Data Analysis.
11. Interoperability Standards and security.
12. Dashboard and Visualization.
13. Documentation and Productization
