Course Description: This course explores the foundational principles and advanced methodologies of signal detection and estimation theory. It rigorously covers optimal estimation techniques, including Minimum Variance Unbiased (MVU) estimation, Cramer-Rao bound, and practical estimators like Maximum Likelihood (MLE), Least Squares (LSE), and Bayesian approaches. Concurrently, it investigates hypothesis testing, Neyman-Pearson criterion, and likelihood ratio tests for optimal signal detection under diverse conditions, ranging from deterministic to random signals with known or unknown parameters. Students will develop analytical and design skills to implement optimal detectors and estimators, applying these robust techniques to complex problems across engineering disciplines.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Estimation Theory - Minimum Variance Unbiased (MVU) Estimation, Cramer Rao lower bound, Fisher Information, Neyman-Fisher factorization, Sufficient and complete test statistics, Rao Blackwell-Lehmann-Scheffe theorem.

Unit 2: Estimation methods - Best linear unbiased estimation (BLUE), Least square estimation (LSE), Maximum likelihood estimation (MLE), Bayesian Approach, Numerical methods - Newton Raphson and Expectation maximization (EM) methods.

Unit 3: Detection Theory - Hypothesis testing, Neyman-Pearson (NP) theorem, Likelihood ratio test (LRT), Receiver operating characteristic (ROC), Minimum probability of error, Bayes Risk, Minimum Bayes risk detector, MAP detector.

Unit 4: Detection methods–Detection of deterministic signals - Matched filter for WGN and non WGN, Binary and M-array signal detection using matched filter. Detection of random signals - Estimator-correlator and linear model; Detection of deterministic signal with unknown parameters - Composite hypothesis testing, Generalized LRT (GLRT), Bayesian approach, Rao test, Wald test.
Generated_LOs: CO1: Analyze the efficiency of minimum variance unbiased estimators by deriving the Cramer–Rao lower bound for linear Gaussian models and computing mean‑square errors in simulated data sets by the term end.

CO2: Design and implement maximum likelihood estimators for nonlinear parameter estimation using Newton–Raphson and Expectation‑Maximization algorithms, assessing convergence rates under varying noise variances by the final project.

CO3: Construct Neyman–Pearson hypothesis tests for binary detection of deterministic signals in white Gaussian noise, derive likelihood‑ratio thresholds for specified false‑alarm probabilities, and plot ROC curves for SNR values between 0–20 dB by semester’s conclusion.

CO4: Apply matched‑filter technique to detect deterministic signals in colored noise, implement filter weighting matrices, and evaluate detection probability and false‑alarm rates against theoretical predictions by end of course.

CO5: Develop generalized likelihood‑ratio tests (GLRT) for composite hypotheses with unknown signal parameters, implement Wald and Rao tests, and compare detection probabilities across different model assumptions using Monte Carlo simulations by course end.

CO6: Evaluate Bayes‑risk minimization in multi‑hypothesis detection, derive MAP detector expressions for known priors, and quantify performance trade‑offs through simulated experiments by semester end.

CO7: Integrate MATLAB/Octave simulation tools to model random signal detection using estimator‑correlator architecture, analyze detection statistics, and report on optimality conditions relative to theoretical bounds by the final assessment.

Course Description: This course explores the fundamental principles of signal processing, starting with continuous-time signal analysis using Fourier Transforms for LTI systems. It then covers sampling, reconstruction, and analog-to-digital conversion, addressing issues like aliasing. The curriculum progresses to discrete-time signals and systems, utilizing DTFT, Z-Transform, and efficient DFT implementations (FFT). A significant focus is on designing FIR and IIR digital filters. Students will develop practical skills in analyzing complex signals and systems, applying various transforms, and designing effective digital filters, preparing them to tackle real-world problems through simulation and research-based analysis.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Fourier transform (FT) of continuous-time signals, analysis of linear and time invariant (LTI) systems using Fourier transform
Unit 2: Sampling and reconstruction of bandlimited signals, analog-to-digital conversion, aliasing, quantization
Unit 3: Analysis of discrete-time signals and systems using Fourier transform (DTFT) and Z- Transform
Unit 4: Discrete Fourier transform (DFT) for finite length sequences, efficient implementation of DFT using radix-2 fast Fourier transform (FFT) algorithms
Unit 5: Digital filter design, techniques for FIR and IIR filter design
Generated_LOs: CO1: Analyze continuous-time Fourier transform expressions of LTI systems to extract magnitude and phase spectra, verifying theoretical predictions with MATLAB simulations.

CO2: Evaluate aliasing effects in analog-to-digital conversion by running simulations across multiple sampling rates, reconstructing signals using sinc interpolation, and reporting reconstruction error metrics.
CO3: Design FIR digital filters via windowing methods to achieve at least 40 dB stopband attenuation at specified cutoff frequencies, and verify performance through MATLAB filter design toolbox.
CO4: Implement radix-2 FFT algorithms in Python/NumPy, achieving a 10× speed improvement over naive DFT on 8192-point signals, and validate results against MATLAB's fft function.

CO5: Construct pole-zero plots for IIR filter prototypes and analyze stability and transient response by calculating impulse responses, demonstrating that the filter meets specified phase linearity criteria.

CO6: Develop a real-time digital filtering application in Python using PyAudio that allows dynamic reconfiguration of filter parameters, and document latency measurements to ensure real-time operation.

Course Description: This course provides a comprehensive exploration of Software Quality Engineering, focusing on the principles and practices essential for designing and analyzing high-quality software systems. It covers fundamental concepts of process and product quality, measurement techniques, and quality tactics within the software development lifecycle, including formal methods and V&V perspectives. Specialized topics include usability, accessibility, secure software engineering, and quality considerations for intelligent systems. By engaging with current research and applying well-established principles, students will develop the ability to critique existing work, identify open problems, and synthesize novel solutions for complex quality challenges.
Detailed Syllabus: The course will cover the following topics: - Process and Product Quality - Measurement Fundamentals – Why, What and How? - Qualities and Tactics - Software Development Life Cycle – V & V perspective - Formal Methods and Quality - Usability and Accessibility - Qualities in intelligent Systems – Model, Data and System - Secure Software Engineering - Other research topics
Generated_LOs: CO1: Define and calculate defect density and reliability metrics for a deployed web service, then evaluate their impact on release readiness and propose evidence-based improvement actions
CO2: Design a continuous integration pipeline integrating static analysis, unit testing, and code coverage tools to enforce minimum quality thresholds for an open-source Java project

CO3: Apply the ISO/IEC 25010 quality model to critique the usability and accessibility compliance of a mobile banking app, and produce a prioritized improvement plan based on empirical usability tests
CO4: Formulate verification and validation test cases using Z formal specification for a payment processing microservice, then demonstrate correctness through model checking and logical proof
CO5: Construct threat models and implement countermeasures for a RESTful API using OWASP Top 10 guidelines, and evaluate residual risk through penetration testing and risk scoring

CO6: Assess the quality of machine-learning components in a recommendation system by computing bias, interpretability, and robustness metrics, and propose mitigation strategies grounded in empirical data

CO7: Synthesize a research proposal that identifies an open problem in software quality for intelligent systems, outlines a methodological approach using formal methods or empirical studies, and justifies its potential impact on industry practice

Course Description: This course introduces foundational principles and practical methodologies for software systems development. It systematically covers essential Unix-like environments and shell scripting for automation. Students will delve into web programming fundamentals, including client-side technologies (HTML, CSS, JavaScript) and server-side scripting with Python. The curriculum further encompasses basic database programming, software development lifecycle (SDLC) concepts, and an overview of networking and security principles crucial for modern applications. Upon completion, students will be proficient in evaluating application ideas, developing diverse scripts and small-to-medium scale applications, and extending existing software solutions.
Detailed Syllabus: Linux and Shell Scripting, HTML, CSS, JavaScript and related libraries, Python, Basics of SDLC, Simple Queries, Networking and Security concepts.
1. Shell Programming - Linux basic commands, script writing, Swiss-army- knife tools (vi, grep, awk, sed ..)
2. Web Programming - Intro to basic concepts of the World Wide Web (WWW) and tools used to develop web apps. -Client-side & server-side scripting (HTML, XHTML, CSS, Java script, Python,)
3. Database Programming, Networking and Security
Generated_LOs: CO1: Design and implement a Linux shell script that automates backup of user directories using tar, rsync, and cron, including error handling and log generation.

CO2: Create a responsive web application prototype with HTML5, CSS3, and vanilla JavaScript that fetches JSON data from a RESTful API, dynamically updates the DOM, and demonstrates client-side interaction using modern ES6 features.

CO3: Develop a Python Flask module that connects to a PostgreSQL database, executes parameterized queries to retrieve and insert data, returns JSON responses, and applies practices to prevent SQL injection attacks.

CO4: Construct a complete SDLC deliverable set for a small‑to‑medium web application, including requirements documentation, UML design diagrams, implementation plan, test cases, deployment strategy, and a risk assessment, and present the deliverables to peers.
CO5: Implement secure client‑server communication in Python using TCP sockets and TLS encryption, demonstrating encrypted data exchange between a Python client and a web browser interface.
CO6: Refactor legacy shell scripts and Python code to improve modularity, readability, and performance, document changes, and measure performance gains using benchmark tests.

Course Description: This course introduces Spatial Informatics, focusing on the principles and applications of Geospatial Information Systems (GIS). It delves into fundamental concepts of space and digital representation of geospatial data, covering techniques for data collection, management, and advanced analysis, including spatial queries and network analysis. The curriculum also explores data compatibility, web-GIS, and 3D GIS. Students will learn to prepare and analyze spatial and temporal data, interpret complex outcomes, and design research projects to address real-world challenges in various domain areas, uncovering critical patterns.
Detailed Syllabus: Course Structure (each of approximately 1–2-week duration):
1. What is Geographical Information Systems (GIS)?
2. Fundamental concepts of Space
3. Geospatial data and its Digital representation – Vectors and Raster
4. GIS Data collection, Editing and Data formats
5. Data structures for Spatial data and Spatial data management (Geospatial database)
6. Spatial Data Query and Analysis – Spatial Analysis, Network Analysis
7. Data compatibility - Projections and Georeferencing
8. Spatial reasoning and uncertainty
9. Web-GIS, GML and Map services
10. Geospatial applications in few areas like in Hydrology (Water flows and floods); Ecology and Environment; Land use and Land cover; Urban planning and Transportation; etc.
11. Topics in Spatial Informatics 1. 3DGIS 2. Open-Source Initiatives inGIS/RS
Generated_LOs: CO1: Design and implement a relational spatial data model in PostGIS to store and index vector layers of a hydrological network, then query network statistics using SQL to demonstrate spatial data management proficiency by semester end.

CO2: Analyze a 3‑D GIS dataset in ArcGIS Pro’s 3D Analyst to calculate watershed surface models, derive slope and aspect, and assess flood risk, presenting quantitative results in a report by the final assessment.

CO3: Create and publish a web‑GIS service with GeoServer and QGIS that delivers WMS/WFS layers, applying dynamic styling and querying capabilities, and demonstrate user interaction in a live demo during the course.

CO4: Evaluate the impact of projection choice on distance calculations by comparing results from Web Mercator and UTM projections for a transportation network dataset, and report discrepancies in a written analysis.

CO5: Develop a GIS‑based decision‑support model that integrates land use, ecological habitat suitability, and climate data to recommend conservation corridors, visualizing outputs in a Python Dash dashboard presented to stakeholders by the final project deadline.

CO6: Construct a network analysis workflow using ArcGIS Network Analyst to calculate optimal travel routes and network centrality metrics for a case‑study city, validating outputs with comparative scenarios in a technical write‑up.

Course Description: This course explores the foundational principles and practical applications of spatial thinking and spatio-temporal analysis. It covers essential methodologies for spatial data acquisition and processing, including traditional surveying techniques, modern Global Navigation Satellite Systems (GNSS), and advanced digital photogrammetry. Students will delve into fundamental concepts of geodesy, earth's gravity field, and error management in geospatial data. The curriculum integrates the conceptualization, representation, and computation of spatial information, equipping learners to implement diverse measurement techniques and critically evaluate their relevance within various geospatial contexts.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit-1: Concept of Space and Time: Geographical entities and Phenomena, Properties of Space, Size and Scale, comprehend spatial and temporal data throughout the processes of conceptualization, representation, computation, and visualization.

Unit-2: Surveying: Principles of Surveying, Measuring equipment, Techniques, Levelling, Triangulation and Trilateration, Plane Table Surveys, Modern surveying equipment- Total Station, The mathematical model and errors, Random and systematic errors, adjustments techniques.

Unit-3: GNSS: Intro to GNSS; GNSS survey, Keplerian laws, inertial coordinate systems etc., Overview of GNSS: GLONASS, GALILEO, BIDOU, IRNSS satellite systems etc., Differential GPS: GNSS Basic Observables: GNSS Surveying Techniques. Planning and field observations: Networking, data post processing. GNSS applications to Global, Regional and Local issues

Unit-4: Digital Photogrammetry: Fundamental principles and techniques of Photogrammetry surveying, camera calibration, image orientation, stereoscopic viewing, and digital image processing, photogrammetric methods for terrain modeling, Digital elevation model (DEM) generation Integration with other geospatial technologies (LiDAR, UAVs).

Unit-5: Geodesy: Introduction to geodesy & its development; Earth and its gravity field. Earth and its atmosphere – physical properties, Introduction to GPS- its components, Instruments & processing software, GPS signals. GPS data collection, Data Handling-, GPS data processing, Errors in GPS data – Satellite Geometry, Multipath errors & corrections; Accuracy of GPS data. Datum transformation. Geoid modelling.
Generated_LOs: CO1: Analyze spatial and temporal patterns of geographic phenomena at multiple scales using GIS tools and produce visualizations that highlight scale-dependent features.
CO2: Construct and apply a least-squares adjusted triangulation network to produce a ground control grid with positional accuracies better than 5 cm.
CO3: Execute differential GNSS surveying procedures, process raw observations, and verify resulting station positions against a reference datum within 30 cm.
CO4: Develop a complete photogrammetric workflow by calibrating a digital camera, performing image orientation, and generating a DEM with vertical accuracy within ±2 m.
CO5: Compute and visualize geoid heights for selected coordinates using the EGM2008 model, and evaluate the impact of local mass variations on total‑station survey accuracy.
CO6: Evaluate systematic and random error sources in GNSS and photogrammetry datasets, quantify their effects on positional precision, and propose mitigation strategies.
CO7: Integrate LiDAR point cloud data and UAV-derived orthophotos to produce a composite high‑resolution orthomosaic, and assess spatial resolution improvements across the study area.

Course Description: This course explores the fundamental principles governing the interaction of matter with electromagnetic radiation across various energy regimes. It systematically covers atomic and molecular spectra, applying both classical and quantum mechanical models to explain electronic, vibrational, and rotational transitions. Detailed discussions include Raman, Infrared, Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR), and Electron Spin Resonance (ESR) spectroscopies. Students will develop the analytical skills to interpret complex spectra, apply theoretical models to spectroscopic phenomena, and calculate molecular properties derived from experimental data.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Introduction: Classical mechanical description of spectroscopy, quantum mechanics and energy quantization, energy-level diagram, energy spectrum: electronic states, vibrational states, rotational states, excitation and relaxation, absorption and emission of electromagnetic waves by materials
Unit 2: Atomic Spectra: Spectral series of hydrogen and alkali atoms, selection rules, L-S coupling, many-electron atoms, isotope shift, hyperfine splitting of spectral lines

Unit 3: Molecular Spectra: Electronic spectra of diatomic and polyatomic molecules, Born- Oppenheimer approximation, Franck-Condon principle, absorption and emission spectra, fluorescence and phosphorescence, Jablonsky diagram, effect of solvation of electronic spectra, rotational spectrum of a diatomic molecule using a rigid rotator model, energy levels and spectrum of a non-rigid diatomic molecule, effect of isotopic substitution on rotational spectra, vibrational spectrum of a diatomic molecule using the harmonic and anharmonic oscillator models. vibrational- rotational coupling in a diatomic molecule, molecular spectra of chain molecules

Unit 4: Raman and Infrared Spectroscopy: Classical and quantum theory of Raman effect, normal vibrations of CO2 and H2O molecules, vibrational and rotational Raman spectra, basic concept of infrared spectroscopy, interpretation of Raman and IR spectra, identification of Raman-active and/or IR-active modes based on symmetry arguments
Unit 5: Introduction to Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR), and Electron Spin Resonance (ESR) spectroscopy
Generated_LOs: CO1: Analyze electronic transition energies of diatomic molecules using the Born–Oppenheimer approximation and compare predicted spectra with experimental absorption data.

CO2: Calculate vibrational energy levels of a diatomic molecule using the harmonic oscillator model, evaluate anharmonic corrections by fitting to infrared spectral peaks, and report the resulting energy corrections.
CO3: Interpret rotational spectra of a non‑rigid diatomic molecule, identify centrifugal distortion constants from spectral line spacing, and compare them with theoretical predictions.

CO4: Apply selection rules derived from L‑S coupling to predict the presence or absence of hyperfine splitting in the atomic spectra of alkali metals, and validate predictions against observed line patterns.

CO5: Construct a Raman and infrared activity table for a given polyatomic molecule using symmetry arguments, and demonstrate how to differentiate Raman‑active versus IR‑active vibrational modes from the spectra.

CO6: Design a basic NMR experiment to determine chemical shifts of a simple organic molecule, calculate J‑coupling constants from the split patterns, and interpret the data to elucidate the molecule’s backbone structure.
CO7: Evaluate ESR spectra of a free radical sample by calculating g‑factors and hyperfine coupling constants, and correlate these with the electronic structure predicted by quantum mechanical models.

Course Description: This course offers a comprehensive exploration of speech analysis and computational linguistics, examining the fundamental linguistic units from phonemes to sentences and their acoustic manifestations. It systematically covers core methodologies for phonemic, prosodic, and text analysis, including advanced topics like visual phonetics, intonation modelling, and neural language models. Students will learn to apply computational linguistics foundations to analyze state-of-the-art speech applications such as ASR and TTS. The curriculum develops practical skills in modeling pronunciation, intonation, and text features, enabling the design of effective algorithms for robust speech processing systems.
Detailed Syllabus: (Please list the order in which they will be covered, and preferably arrange these as five to six modules.)
Unit-1: Speech and linguistic basics -- Description of frames, phonemes, syllables, words, phrases, sentences and its use in speech-based feature computation.
Unit-2: Linguistics in speech analysis -- Overview of speech applications (such as ASR, TTS, Speech pathology etc..), use of phonemes, graphemes, prosody and text.

Unit-3: Phonemic analysis -- Phonemes and its accents, visual phonetics (Spectrogram, articulatory videos), pronunciation variations and modelling, grapheme to phoneme conversion, phoneme accent variations and identification.

Unit-4: Prosodic analysis -- Prosodic structure, word and syllable prominence, prominence detection and its applications, Intonation and its modelling (such as ToBI etc..), pitch and prominence variations, intonation identification, pauses, disfluencies and its detection, speech rhythm and speaking rate.
Unit-5: Text analysis -- language modelling, neural language models, metrics, text normalization, character-based speech analysis.
Generated_LOs: CO1: Identify and extract phoneme boundaries from raw audio recordings using signal processing techniques, and visualize them on spectrograms to confirm accurate segmentation.
CO2: Analyze prosodic features—including pitch contour, energy, and duration—to classify sentence-level stress patterns by applying ToBI annotation schemes within a computational tool.

CO3: Design a grapheme-to-phoneme conversion model that incorporates pronunciation variant dictionaries for a target language, and evaluate its accuracy against a curated gold-standard pronunciation corpus.
CO4: Implement an automatic intonation detection module in Python that employs a neural pitch tracker or Kaldi PFSTs to segment speech into rise/fall patterns and output ToBI labels.
CO5: Evaluate a neural language model such as BERT or GPT for spoken text normalization by measuring perplexity and token mapping accuracy on a multilingual dataset.
CO6: Construct an ASR-enhancement pipeline that integrates phoneme, prosodic, and lexical features, and demonstrate a minimum 5% relative error reduction on a benchmark speech corpus by course end.

Course Description: This course provides a comprehensive foundation in speech signal processing, focusing on the intricate mechanisms of human speech. It delves into the fundamental principles of speech production and perception, progressing to detailed analysis techniques. Topics include LTI speech modeling, extraction of key speech events like pitch and formants, and advanced analytical methods such as STFT, linear prediction, and cepstral analysis. The course also examines prosody and excitation source characteristics. Ultimately, students will be equipped to understand and design algorithms for various speech processing applications, including recognition, synthesis, and speaker identification.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Overview of signal processing, speech production, speech perception, typesof speech, and LTI model of speech production.
Unit 2: Pitch, formants, epochs and vowel region extraction.
Unit 3: Speech analysis: STFT analysis, Linear prediction analysis and cepstralanalysis.
Unit 4: Prosody analysis and excitation source analysis of speech.
Unit-5: Applications of speech processing such as speech recognition, speakerrecognition and speech synthesis.
Generated_LOs: CO1: Analyze the time-frequency characteristics of a speech signal using short‑time Fourier transform (STFT) to identify and label phonetic events such as vowels, consonants, and glottal stops, and report findings in a lab report.

CO2: Design a linear predictive coding (LPC) model that captures the vocal tract transfer function for a given speaker, implement it in MATLAB/Python, and compare the synthesis quality against a reference waveform.

CO3: Implement a pitch extraction algorithm (e.g., autocorrelation or YIN) on a subset of the dataset, evaluate its precision and recall against hand‑annotated ground truth, and present a performance summary.
CO4: Construct a formant tracking workflow that extracts and visualizes F1–F3 contours for vowel sounds across speakers, and demonstrate the system’s ability to discriminate between vowel categories.

CO5: Evaluate the effectiveness of a prosody‑based emotion recognition model by training on annotated prosodic features and computing classification accuracy, sensitivity, and specificity, and report the results.

CO6: Apply cepstral analysis to separate the excitation source from the vocal tract, then use the source–filter parameterization to improve a concatenative speech synthesis system, and compare synthesized voice intelligibility before and after the modification.

Course Description: This course establishes the fundamental mathematical and computational principles for statistical machine learning in Artificial Intelligence. It begins with data representation, feature vectors, distributions, and dimensionality reduction techniques. The core explores essential algorithms like PCA, Perceptrons, and Decision Trees, advancing to unsupervised learning, Support Vector Machines, and concepts of bias-variance trade-off. The final unit introduces Neural Network learning, Multi-Layer Perceptrons, Backpropagation, and an exposure to Deep Learning. Upon completion, students will be able to formulate complex problems as classification/regression tasks, explain the mathematical ideas behind popular ML algorithms, and critically analyze the practical and computational challenges in designing and implementing these systems on real-world data.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Representation, Vectors, Distributions, Dimensionality reduction, problems and challenges in machine learning
Unit 2: Basic algorithms in machine learning, PCA, Perceptron’s, Decision Trees, Analysis
Unit 3: Popular algorithms and settings including unsupervised learning, Support Vector Machines, Kernels, Bias and Variance, Model Selection.
Unit 4: Neural Network Learning, Multi-Layer Perceptron, Backpropagation Algorithms, Exposure to Deep Learning.
Generated_LOs: CO1: Analyze and compare the effectiveness of PCA vs. kernel PCA in reducing dimensionality while retaining classification accuracy on a multi-class dataset, and report quantitative metrics such as explained variance and misclassification rates

CO2: Design and implement a perceptron and a decision tree classifier in Python, employ 5-fold cross-validation, and evaluate their performance using confusion matrices, precision, recall, and F1 scores
CO3: Evaluate the bias-variance trade-off in support vector machines by tuning C and gamma parameters, demonstrate the impact on training vs. test error, and summarize findings with learning curves

CO4: Construct and train a multi-layer perceptron with backpropagation using a deep learning library (e.g., PyTorch), optimize hyperparameters through grid search, and achieve at least a 10% accuracy improvement over a linear baseline on a benchmark image dataset

CO5: Critically analyze the computational cost of stochastic vs. batch gradient descent when training deep networks on large datasets, and propose adaptive strategies (e.g., learning rate schedules, mini-batch sizing) to improve convergence time

CO6: Implement unsupervised clustering techniques (K-means, hierarchical) on a real-world dataset, compute silhouette scores and Davies-Bouldin indices, and interpret the clustering validity in the context of domain knowledge

Course Description: This course provides the knowledge and skills to mathematically model and analyze the dynamic response of structural systems. It covers the formulation of equations of motion for Single- and Multi-Degree of Freedom (SDOF, MDOF) systems, exploring free and forced vibrations, damping, and mode superposition. The curriculum details numerical and approximate methods for computing natural frequencies, including Eigenvalue problems, Ritz vectors, and direct integration techniques. A major focus is on base-excited systems, response spectrum concepts, and their application in earthquake engineering, referencing codes like IS 1893. Students will be able to employ computational tools to predict and improve structural response to dynamic loading.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Response of simple Single Degree of Freedom (SDOF) systems Introduction to structural dynamics; Definition of DOF; idealization of structure as SDOF system; Formulation of equations of motion for various SDOF systems; Free vibration of systems; Damping in structures; Undamped Systems; Forced vibration of systems; Steady state response to harmonic forces; Experimental determinations of natural frequency; Duhamel's integral and other methods.

Unit 2: Analysis of Multi-Degree of Freedom (MDOF) systems Static force displacement relationship; Strain energy of system; Formulation of equation of motion; Evaluation of natural frequencies and modes; Free vibration of undamped systems; Forced vibration of damped systems; Review of time history & response spectrum methods.

Unit 3: Numerical Methods, and Approximate methods of computing natural frequencies Eigen value problems and applications: Mode superposition principle; modal truncation errors; Ritz Vector approach; Direct Integration methods: Explicit methods - Central difference method; Implicit methods - Newmark-ß method; Rayleigh's method; Dunkerley's method; Rayleigh-Ritz method

Unit 4: Base excited systems Formulation of equations of motion for SDOF and MDOF systems; Concept of spectral quantities; Response spectrum; Fundamentals of earthquake engineering; Discussion onIS 1893 (1:2016 provisions for buildings.
Unit 5: Overview of dynamics of continuous systems Vibration of flexural beams and shear beams: Equation of motion; Free vibration and Forced vibration
Generated_LOs: CO1: Formulate and solve the differential equation of motion for a damped SDOF system subject to harmonic excitation, demonstrating the derivation and evaluation of steady‑state displacement amplitude.

CO2: Compute natural frequencies and mode shapes for a 4‑DOF mechanical system by solving the eigenvalue problem and validate the results using the Rayleigh‑Ritz approximation, comparing modal truncation errors.

CO3: Implement the Newmark‑β method to perform time‑integration of a 3‑DOF structure under ground acceleration data within a MATLAB or Python environment, generating time histories and assessing numerical stability.

CO4: Evaluate the response spectrum of a base‑excited building model according to IS 1893 provisions, determine design base shear values, and confirm that the selected design satisfies seismic safety criteria.

CO5: Construct a finite element model of a composite beam subjected to transient loading, extract free vibration characteristics, and compare the numerical results with analytical beam theory predictions.

CO6: Analyze the effect of varying damping ratios on the steady‑state displacement response of a 2‑DOF system, and recommend an optimal damping value for seismic isolation based on performance indices.

Course Description: This design studio integrates structural analysis concepts with computational methods for the comprehensive design of structural systems. The course begins with a review of classical structural analysis techniques for trusses and frames, followed by an introduction to fundamental numerical methods. A significant focus is placed on using MATLAB for developing custom structural analysis software, covering everything from linear algebra to GUI tool creation for analyzing beams and frames under various loads. Finally, students gain practical experience with commercial software (STAAD, SAP2000, ETABS) for elastic and dynamic (Modal, Response Spectrum, Time History) analysis and design of Reinforced Concrete and Steel buildings. This equips students to analyze and design components and systems efficiently.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Review of Structural Analysis – Analysis of Planar Trusses, Shear Force and Bending Moment Diagrams, Structural Analysis-Force Methods-Displacement Methods, Deflected Shape- Deflections, Approximate Methods of Analysis- Gravity and Lateral Loads-Beams, Frames.
Unit 2: Numerical Methods – Bi-Section Method, Gauss Elimination, Newton-Raphson

Unit 3: Introduction to MATLAB – Vectors, Arrays and Matrices, Branching Statements and Loops, Introduction to Plotting, Linear Algebra, Curve Fitting, Script and Functions, Graphics -2D and 3D, Development of GUI Tool.
Unit 4: Application of MATLAB – Analysis of Beams & Frames, Gravity and Lateral Load Analysis of Frames, Analysis of Planar Trusses.

Unit 5: Introduction to STAAD, SAP2000 & ETABS – Modelling, Analysis and Design Concepts, Elastic Analysis and Design-Reinforced Concrete Building -Bare Frame Analysis, Analysis of Frames with Unreinforced Masonry Infills, Steel Building, Elastic Earthquake Behaviour of Buildings- Modal Analysis-Linear Dynamic Analyses and Design-Response Spectrum Analysis, Time History Analysis, Introduction to Inelastic Earthquake Behaviour of Buildings-Nonlinear Static Analysis Essentials- Nonlinear Static Analysis.
Generated_LOs: CO1: Conduct detailed force and displacement analysis of planar trusses using classical matrix methods and verify results with analytical solutions.
CO2: Apply Newton–Raphson and Gauss–Elimination numerical techniques to solve the system of nonlinear equations for beam bending under variable loading.
CO3: Design and implement a MATLAB-based GUI that generates shear‐force, bending‐moment, and deflection plots for frames loaded with gravity and lateral forces.
CO4: Evaluate the elastic stability of a reinforced concrete building in ETABS by performing modal, response‑spectrum, and time‑history analyses and confirming compliance with ASCE 7 criteria.
CO5: Construct a multi‑storey steel frame model in STAAD Engineering, incorporate realistic seismic base sills and inelastic capacity spectrum analysis, and detail the unreinforced masonry infill.
CO6: Compare commercial and custom software outputs by reproducing a given beam response to a static load in MATLAB and SAP2000, quantifying discrepancies within 5% and explaining the causes.

Course Description: This course focuses on evaluating the structural safety and integrity of built infrastructure to prevent collapses. It introduces assessment methods ranging from rapid visual inspection and simple techniques like thrust line analysis to advanced computational methods. The curriculum delves into failure theories, material modeling (continuous, micro, macro), and numerical techniques such as Finite Element and Discrete Element methods for accurate structural assessment. A significant component covers the application and principles of various Non-Destructive Testing (NDT) techniques. Through case studies and reliability-based methods, students develop the proficiency to evaluate existing structures, analyze structural failures, and propose effective rehabilitation schemes.
Detailed Syllabus: Module 1: Introduction to structural assessment, structural collapse, choice of assessment method based on available information, type of collapse, and level of assessment. Rapid visual inspection, relevant recommendations, simple methods: thrust line analysis, stability under self-weight, gravity loads, lateral loads, equilibrium governing systems.

Module 2: Computational methods in structural assessment: failure theories for ductile and brittle materials, material models: continuous, micro and macro models, modelling techniques: Finite element method, discrete element method.
Module 3: Non-Destructive Testing (NDT) Techniques, Overview of non-destructive testing methods, Application of NDT in structural assessment. Introduction to structural reliability.
Module 4: Case Studies: Detailed discussion of case studies on structural failures of built infrastructure, indicators and rehabilitation schemes.
Generated_LOs: CO1: Analyze rapid visual inspection observations to produce a quantitative collapse risk assessment report for a specified structure.
CO2: Design and apply thrust line analysis models to evaluate tipping and overturning stability of gravity‑loaded masonry or concrete walls under defined self‑weight and lateral load scenarios.
CO3: Evaluate finite element simulation results using ductile and brittle failure theories (e.g., Rankine, von Mises) to identify critical failure zones in a given structure.
CO4: Implement discrete element method simulations to model progressive collapse of a masonry bridge and compute the critical load initiating failure.
CO5: Demonstrate the application of ultrasonic C‑scan and ground‑penetrating radar NDT techniques to detect internal defects in concrete columns and assess their impact on structural integrity.

CO6: Formulate a reliability‑based rehabilitation plan for a case‑study structure by integrating failure probability calculations with cost‑benefit analysis to propose optimal reinforcement strategies.

Course Description: This course provides an introduction to Systems Biology, focusing on the quantitative analysis and modeling of complex biological networks. It begins by examining the organization of biological networks, including motifs, modules, and hierarchical structures. The core of the course explores the design principles that govern biological systems. A major focus is placed on the dynamic mathematical modeling of biochemical systems, which includes analyzing concepts such as Biological Switches, Clocks, and the inherent robustness of these systems. Students will gain the ability to infer the underlying design principles and analyze biological systems rigorously through mathematical modeling.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Network organization: Motifs, modules, and hierarchical networks
Unit 2: Design principles of biological systems
Unit 3: Dynamic modelling of biochemical systems
Unit 4: Biological Switches and Clocks,
Unit 5: Robustness of Biological systems
Unit 5: Biological noise
Generated_LOs: CO1: Analyze biological network organization by identifying motifs, modules, and hierarchical structures using graph metrics and evaluate their functional significance in a detailed written report
CO2: Design kinetic differential equation models for biochemical switches, parameterize them with literature data, and simulate bistability behavior using MATLAB/SimBiology
CO3: Evaluate the robustness of a cell cycle oscillator model by performing parameter perturbations, computing sensitivity indices, and presenting quantitative results in a comparison table
CO4: Construct a stochastic Gillespie simulation of noisy gene expression, analyze the resulting probability distributions, and report mean, variance, and noise characteristics

CO5: Implement a linear feedback control strategy to stabilize a circadian clock model under parameter uncertainty, tune control gains using machine learning, and assess performance with error metrics

CO6: Demonstrate inference of design principles in biological rhythms by aligning experimental time‑series data with model predictions, interpreting phase relationships, and summarizing findings in a comprehensive lab report

Course Description: This course introduces the principles of Systems Thinking through mathematical modeling and control theory, with applications extending to biological systems. It covers the development of system models via transfer functions and state-space formulation, followed by rigorous time-domain performance and stability analysis for first and second-order systems. The curriculum addresses the design and development of Proportional, Integral, and Derivative (PID) controllers. Finally, the course transitions to biological applications, exploring biological signals, system design principles, control mechanisms, and the modeling and design of biological circuits. Students will be able to apply first principles to develop system models and use control theory to analyze and design both engineering and biological systems.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Mathematical modelling of systems via transfer functions and state-space
Unit 2: Time-domain performance and stability analysis of first and second order systems
Unit 3: Biological signals and systems (case study)
Unit 4: Design principles of biological systems and control
Unit 6: Modeling and design of biological circuits
Generated_LOs: CO1: Formulate a continuous‑time dynamical system as a transfer function and state‑space representation from engineering specifications, and validate the model against experimental data.
CO2: Analyze the stability of first‑order and second‑order systems using root‑locus and damping‑ratio criteria to predict step‑response characteristics that meet predefined performance targets.
CO3: Design a PID controller for a given first‑order plant to achieve specified rise time and overshoot limits, and implement the controller in MATLAB/Simulink to demonstrate closed‑loop behavior.

CO4: Apply biological signal‑processing methods to a physiological time series, extract dominant frequency components, and construct an equivalent linear ODE model that captures the system’s main dynamics.
CO5: Evaluate the robustness of a biological feedback circuit by simulating parameter perturbations in Python and quantifying the resulting changes in steady‑state error and stability margins.

CO6: Create an ODE‑based modular biological circuit model in Python using SciPy, optimize parameters to produce sustained oscillations, and verify the system’s behavior against target frequency and amplitude specifications.

Course Description: This course provides a foundational understanding of the Theory of Elasticity, distinguishing it from Strength of Materials and emphasizing mathematical rigor. It begins with the fundamental concepts of stress, strain, traction, and the necessary mathematical preliminaries, including tensor and matrix representation. The core of the course establishes the governing equations of elasticity: generalized Hook’s law, equilibrium equations, strain-displacement relations, and compatibility conditions. It then applies these principles to formulate and solve 2D boundary value problems using stress functions and the biharmonic equation, specifically for plane stress and plane strain states. The course concludes with an analysis of torsion, bending, and elastic stability, enabling students to idealize physical systems and derive solutions for complex problems.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Elasticity and its types, Inelastic material, Difference between theory of elasticity and strength of material, Materials and its properties, Assumptions in elasticity, Mathematical preliminaries: cartesian co-ordinates, introduction to tensor, matrix representation, operators and symbols.

Unit 2: Concept of stresses and strains, Infinitesimal area and volume, 2D and 3D stress tensor, Stress and strain transformation at a point in an elastic body, Difference between stress and traction, Cauchy’s stress, Components of traction, Strain tensors, Types of deformation, Measurement of surface strains

Unit 3: Rigid body translation and rotation of an element in space, Generalized Hook’s law, Stress- strain relationships, Equilibrium equations, Strain-displacement relationships, Compatibility conditions, Constitutive relations.

Unit 4: Principal planes, Principal stresses and invariants, Octahedral plane and stresses, Deviatoric stress, Hydrostatic stress, Plain stress, Plain strain, Formulation of boundary value problems in equilibrium and compatibility, Stress functions, Biharmonic equation, Solution of 2D problems by the use of polynomials.

Unit 5: Torsion of bars, Saint venant principle, Rigid body rotation, bending of beams, Elastic stability, Factors affecting lateral stability, Analysis of beam-column with different loading conditions, Different types of buckling.
Generated_LOs: CO1: Analyze tensor representations of stress and strain to identify principal stresses and corresponding principal directions in three-dimensional elastic bodies
CO2: Derive and apply generalized Hooke's law for isotropic materials to compute stress components from given strain components and material constants within plane stress and plane strain conditions

CO3: Formulate and solve two-dimensional boundary value problems in elasticity using Airy stress functions and the biharmonic equation to determine stress distributions for specified loadings and boundary conditions
CO4: Evaluate elastic stability of prismatic columns by computing critical buckling loads using Euler's formula and incorporating effects of initial imperfection and boundary constraints
CO5: Design torsional rigidity analyses for circular and non-circular shafts by constructing shear stress distributions and calculating torsional constants using Saint-Venant's principles
CO6: Implement numerical verification of analytical elasticity solutions by discretizing governing equations into finite difference schemes and comparing results for benchmark problems

Course Title: Thinking and Knowing in the Human Sciences – II
Course Description: This course explores methods of thinking and knowing about society through the lenses of history and sociology. It introduces fundamental sociological concepts such as social structures, culture, and deviance, followed by an in-depth study of major theoretical frameworks for understanding social stratification, including Structural Functionalist, Marxist, and Weberian approaches. The course also examines social institutions and processes specific to India. On the historical side, it analyzes different ideas of history (Progress, Decline) and the main methods of knowing the past, such as structuralism and post-structuralism, alongside concepts of time and space. Students will gain experience in using sociological and historiographical theories to critically engage with and analyze complex social phenomena.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Sociological Concepts: Social Structures, Individuals and Groups, Socialisation, Structure/Agency, Status and Roles, Rules, Values, Norms, Culture, Discourse, Deviance.

Unit 2: Sociological Frameworks and Theories: Understanding social stratification through the structural functionalist, Marxist and the Weberian methods. Introduction to key ideas of Emile Durkheim, Karl Marx and Max Weber.
Unit 3: Social Institutions and Processes in India.
Unit 4: Ideas of History (Progress, Decline, Morality; Facts, Objectivity, Interpretation)
Unit 5: Concepts of Time and Space
Unit 6: Main methods of knowing the past (Inductive and deductive methods; structuralism and post-structuralism).
Generated_LOs: CO1: Analyze the interplay between social structure, individual agency, and deviance within a selected Indian social institution by critiquing at least two concrete case studies presented during the semester.

CO2: Evaluate Marxist and Weberian theoretical frameworks to compare their explanatory power regarding caste-based social stratification in India, producing a comparative matrix that highlights key assumptions and empirical relevance.

CO3: Construct a historiographical argument that situates the notion of progress versus decline in Indian historical thought, drawing upon Marxist and structuralist sources studied in the course to support the thesis.

CO4: Apply inductive and deductive reasoning to design a research proposal investigating how digital media influences youth socialization in India, including sampling strategy, variable operationalization, and data collection methods.

CO5: Critically assess post‑structuralist interpretations of time and space in one primary historical source, demonstrating how discursive construction shapes the historical narrative and its implications for contemporary society.

CO6: Synthesize sociological and historical methodologies to evaluate a contemporary social issue in India, producing a concise analytical report that integrates core sociological concepts, theoretical frameworks, and historiographical evidence.

Course Description: This course focuses on the theory and application of optimization techniques essential for modern data science. It begins by establishing a rigorous foundation in convex analysis, covering convex sets, functions, duality, and the formulation of convex optimization problems. The core of the curriculum is dedicated to exploring and analyzing various optimization solvers, including classical methods like Steepest Descent and Newton methods, as well as modern stochastic algorithms like SGD, RMSprop, and ADAM, with a focus on convergence estimates and complexity analysis. The course concludes by demonstrating the practical application of these methods in key data science areas such as Support Vector Machines, Neural Networks, Recommender Systems, and GANs. Students will be equipped to model applications as optimization problems, code efficient solvers, and apply them in research.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Convex Sets, Convex Functions, Duality, Convex Optimization Problems (9 hours)
Unit 2: Steepest Descent, Newton methods, Quasi-Newton Methods, Interior Point Methods, Stochastic Optimization algorithms (SGD, RMSprop, ADAM, SVRG, etc.), Convergence Estimates (6 hours)

Unit 3: Applications of optimization: Recommender Systems, Support Vector Machines, Neural networks, Image, and Video Completion, Extreme Classification, Gans (9 hours) - A project related to the above syllabus will be done by students.
Generated_LOs: CO1: Construct a convex optimization model for binary classification using support vector machine (SVM) formulation and verify dual feasibility conditions with analytical proofs
CO2: Analyze convergence rates of steepest descent versus Newton's method on a strongly convex quadratic problem, compute theoretical worst‑case iteration bounds, and validate them experimentally

CO3: Implement the Adam stochastic optimization algorithm in Python with PyTorch, train a small neural network on MNIST, and benchmark convergence speed and Generalization performance against SGD and RMSprop

CO4: Design and solve a recommendation system problem using matrix factorization with stochastic gradient descent, report convergence diagnostics, and evaluate recommendation quality using Recall@10 and NDCG metrics

CO5: Develop an end‑to‑end project that formulates a GAN training objective as a non‑convex optimization problem, select an appropriate solver, and assess generated image quality using the Fréchet Inception Distance

CO6: Evaluate the computational complexity of interior point methods for linear programming instances derived from data compression tasks, and propose practical runtime improvements based on sparsity exploitation

Course Description: This course explores the interdisciplinary field of Nanoscience, focusing on the unique properties, synthesis, and applications of nanomaterials. The curriculum establishes foundational concepts, including length scales, surface energy, and the classification of nanomaterials (clusters, nanoparticles). A core focus is on how nanoscale confinement effects lead to distinct electrical, optical, magnetic, and thermal properties. The course covers both top-down and bottom-up synthesis methods and introduces the essential tools for nano-system characterization, such as AFM, SEM, and TEM. Emphasis is placed on real-world applications in catalysis, sensing, quantum devices, and theragnostics, concluding with a critical discussion on the environmental and health hazards of nanotechnology. Students will analyze size- and shape-dependent properties and identify suitable experimental techniques for nanoscale research.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1. Introduction to Nanoscience. (3L) Nanomaterials: Definitions and Scopes. Length Scales: Size Scales, Surface and Interface, Surface Energy, Coordination Numbers. Classification of nanomaterials: Clusters and Magic Numbers, Nanoparticles, and Colloids. Metal, Semiconductor, and Bio Nanomaterials.

Unit 2. Properties of Nanomaterials. (9L) Electrons in Nanostructures. Discrete states vs. band structure: Effects of dimensionality and symmetry in nanostructures. Metal-to-nonmetal transition. Thermodynamics and Kinetics of Small-Sized Systems. Capillarity, Liquid droplets, Lotus effect. Self- assembly principles. Adsorption, Electrostatic and Steric Stabilization. Classical nucleation theory. Size and shape control in nanoparticle formation. Magnetic (Super paramagnetism), Electrical (quantized conduction and Coulomb Staircase), Optical (size and shape effects), Thermal (melting and conduction), Mechanical and Catalytic properties.
Unit 3. Making Nanostructures. (3L) Top-down and bottom-up methods.
Unit 4. Tools for Nano systems. Microstructure/Chemistry/Defects and Structure. (5L) AFM, SEM, TEM, XRD, SAXS, Nanoindentation.

Unit 5. Applications of Nanomaterials. (4L) Catalysis, Band Gap Engineered Quantum Devices, Sensors, Field Effect Transistor (FET), Photoelectrochemical Cells, Photonic Crystals and Waveguides, Theragnostics (Magnetothermal Therapy), food and agriculture industries, automobile, textile, water treatment and civil applications, use in energy, space, and defense.
Unit 6. Concerns and Challenges of Nanotechnology. (2L) Environmental, ecological and health hazards of nanoparticles. Nanotoxicology and its effect.
Generated_LOs: CO1: Compare discrete electronic energy levels of quantum dots with bulk semiconductor band structures and predict photoluminescence peak shifts for a given size distribution.

CO2: Design a bottom‑up colloidal synthesis protocol to produce monodisperse gold nanoparticles of 5 nm diameter with polydispersity index below 5 %, selecting surfactants and reducing agents to achieve the target size distribution.

CO3: Fabricate a 50 nm wide nanowire using top‑down lithography, use SEM to measure width variation, and calculate the expected electron transport regime (quantum versus diffusive) based on the measured dimensions.

CO4: Interpret TEM diffraction patterns to determine the crystallographic phase and particle size of nickel oxide nanoparticles synthesized by solvothermal method, and report lattice parameters with quantified uncertainty.

CO5: Calculate the turnover frequency of a Pt‑nanoparticle catalyst for methanol oxidation from chronoamperometric data and compare the performance to a bulk Pt catalyst to evaluate size‑dependent catalytic enhancement.

CO6: Outline the dissolution kinetics of 40 nm silica nanoparticles in simulated body fluid, estimate the skin absorption equivalent dose using OECD 424 guidelines, and assess the potential environmental hazard based on the calculated values.

Course Description: This course provides a practical framework for conducting rigorous User Research, integrating both qualitative and quantitative methodologies. It introduces a 3-dimensional approach using attitudinal, behavioral, quantitative, and qualitative methods in various contexts of use, including field studies, stakeholder interviews, and lab-based observations like eye-tracking. A significant focus is placed on the ethical conduct of user studies, covering the code of conduct, informed consent, privacy, and data safety. The final component addresses data analysis, including thematic qualitative analysis and statistical techniques for data visualization and presentation of user research results. Students will learn to design and execute studies, evaluate user needs, and synthesize findings to identify problems and generate design solutions.

Course Description: This course introduces students to the basic framework of universal human values, encouraging deep self-exploration and the development of a holistic worldview. It examines fundamental aspirations, such as Happiness and Prosperity, and the role of education and conduct in achieving them. The core curriculum focuses on understanding and living in harmony at four interconnected levels: self, family, society, and nature. Key concepts include the right understanding of physical facilities, the foundational values of Trust and Respect in relationships, and the principles of justice and peace in society. The course culminates in an appreciation of Nature and Sustainability, drawing on ideas of self-reliance. This sensitization enables students to understand their roles within a larger context and think critically about shaping the world.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Goal in life - short term and long-term goals; Basic aspirations - Happiness and Prosperity; Role of education and human conduct; Self-exploration; Developing a holistic view
Unit 2: Gratitude and the need to acknowledge one’s gratefulness; Understanding Self and Other.
Unit 3: Living in harmony at 4 levels: self-self, self-family, self-society, self-nature

Unit 4: Understanding needs of body and self; Right understanding of physical facilities and relationships; Understanding human relationships; Trust and Respect - the foundational values in relationships.
Unit5: Harmony in Society; The sense of safety, justice and peace in society; Nature and Sustainability; Self-reliance and Gandhian thought
Generated_LOs: CO1: Analyze personal short-term and long-term goal-setting frameworks and map them to the values of happiness and prosperity within the course duration.
CO2: Design a gratitude-based self-reflection activity that enhances trust and respect in family relationships, to be implemented by mid-semester.
CO3: Evaluate the effectiveness of trust and respect protocols in resolving interpersonal conflicts in community settings, using pre- and post-intervention assessments.
CO4: Construct a sustainable personal routine that integrates physical well-being and environmental stewardship, documented in a reflective journal.
CO5: Demonstrate the application of Gandhian self-reliance principles to develop a community-safety project promoting justice and peace, presented in the final report.
CO6: Develop a communication plan that incorporates justice and peace messaging for an educational institution, incorporating stakeholder feedback by semester end.
CO7: Assess the impact of nature-based sustainability practices on communal health outcomes using mixed-methods analysis by the course conclusion.

Course Description: This course provides a comprehensive study of Very Large Scale Integration (VLSI) Design, focusing on CMOS technology and circuit optimization. It begins with an introduction to the VLSI design flow, MOSFET/FinFET transistors, and the detailed analysis of the CMOS inverter's static and dynamic characteristics (delay, power, noise margin). The core curriculum extends these principles to the design of fundamental digital building blocks like gates, latches, and flip-flops. A major emphasis is placed on delay optimization for multistage logic circuits using the Method of Logical Effort, and exploring alternative logic styles such as Pass Transistor and Dynamic Logic. Concluding with an introduction to system design using HDL, students will gain the skills to analyze, design, and verify delay-optimized combinational and sequential CMOS circuits.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1 (Introduction to VLSI design):1) Introduction to VLSI design (top-bottom approach) - flow, applications, technologies, 2) MOSFET, FinFET transistors – Geometry and model, 3) Introduction to basic building blocks - SPICE, HDL, layout, 4) Moore’s law, technology scaling, current trends(5- lectures/7.5-hours)

Unit 2 (CMOS Inverter): 1) Static characteristics- VTC, switching threshold, Noise margin, 2) Dynamic characteristics – rise time, fall time, delay, power, 3) Why CMOS Inverter, 4) CMOS inverter design flow- problem of achieving higher speeds (solution/technique discussed in the following unit), 5) From inverters to other logic - pull-up, pull-down networks, tristate inverter, Gates, Mux, Latches, Flip-flops, set-up hold time, clocked CMOS and true single phase clocked (TSPC) latches (7- lectures/10.5-hours)

Unit 3 (Multistage Logic Design and Optimization: 1) Parasitics in layout causing performance degradation – field transistor, active MOS, gate-drain overlap, latch-up, 2) Method of logical effort- fan-out, Stage effort, electrical effort, device sizing, design examples. (5-lectures/7.5-hours)
Unit 4 (Other Logic Styles): Pseudo nMOS, pass transistor logic, Cascode Voltage Switch Logic (CVSL), Dynamic logic. (3-lecturs/4.5-hours)

Unit 5 (Other topics Introduction to System Design using HDL): Finite state machines – Mealy, Moore, Intro to RTL,Data path, Control unit, combinational and sequential circuit design examples (6-lectures/9-hours)
Generated_LOs: CO1: Analyze static and dynamic characteristics (VTC, switching threshold, noise margin, rise/fall times, delay, power) of a CMOS inverter using SPICE simulations to quantify performance trade‑offs for scalable process nodes.

CO2: Design and size a CMOS inverter that achieves a specified switching threshold and maximum output noise margin at 10 nm FinFET technology while maintaining target delay, by applying device sizing equations and validating via simulation.

CO3: Construct multistage logic circuits optimized for minimum delay using the Method of Logical Effort, selecting appropriate fan‑out, stage effort, and electrical effort parameters, and evaluate the resulting delay improvement relative to a baseline design.

CO4: Implement pass‑transistor and dynamic logic gates in Verilog‑RTL, synthesize them to a target CMOS technology, and compare their area, delay, and power characteristics against conventional static CMOS gates.

CO5: Verify the functional correctness and timing of sequential circuits (flip‑flops, TSPC latches, FSMs) using HDL simulation and formal verification tools, ensuring setup/hold margins and clock constraints are satisfied.

CO6: Integrate a finite‑state machine into a datapath designed in HDL, simulate its operation on a given testbench, and evaluate the overall system performance in terms of throughput and resource utilization.

Course Title: Work, Entrepreneurship and Technology in Contemporary Societies.
Course Description: This course offers a critical sociological examination of the interconnected spheres of work, entrepreneurship, and technology in contemporary societies. It begins by exploring the foundational theories and historical discourses of work, covering diverse forms, including formal, informal, productive, and reproductive labor, and analyzing the influence of social institutions like gender and caste. The curriculum then introduces the concept of entrepreneurship, investigating different types, from Silicon Valley to self-employed enterprises, and the role of finance, capital, and social networks in these processes. A final module focuses on the historical transformation of technology and its role as an institution that shapes work relations and contingent labor. Students will develop a critical outlook to analyze how technology drives and is adopted within these deeply connected economic engagements.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit-1 Sociology of work: - Theories and basic concepts of work. - Historical discourses and practices around work. - Introduction to sectoral (agriculture, manufacturing, and service) understanding of work in contemporary markets.

Unit-2 Diverse forms of work: Formal and informal work, and productive and reproductive work. Debt and bondage in labour markets; precarity and dignity within contemporary work arrangements. Role of social institutions (gender, caste, and technology) in shaping work and work relations.

Unit-3 Introduction to entrepreneurship: Definition of entrepreneurship, historical discourses in the sociology of entrepreneurship: charismatic individuals, entrepreneurial groups, entrepreneurship as a process. Types of entrepreneurial engagements: Silicon Valley entrepreneurs, intrapreneurship, main-street entrepreneurs, and self-employed entrepreneurs.

Unit-4 Entrepreneurial processes and outcomes: Value creation and the role of finance in entrepreneurship. Role of social networks (kinship and peer networks) in the entrepreneurial process. Reciprocity and resources within entrepreneurial ventures.

Unit-5 Technology and contemporary economy: Historical transformation technology from the 19th century to the present – highlighting key phases of technological transformation, Globalization and technological adoption, Contingent work and digital technology, Role of technology in contemporary entrepreneurship, and technology as an institution.
Generated_LOs: CO1: Analyze the evolution of work theory from Marxian to modern human capital frameworks by constructing a comparative matrix of key propositions and assessing their relevance in today's gig economy.
CO2: Evaluate how gender, caste, and technology intersect to shape informal labor markets by conducting structured stakeholder interviews and applying intersectionality theory to interpret findings.

CO3: Design a comprehensive entrepreneurship pitch deck that integrates value‑creation pathways, financing options, and social network leverage strategies for a selected industry segment, and present it to a panel.

CO4: Construct a data‑driven case study tracing the adoption of a specific digital technology (e.g., AI‑driven HR software) from inception to institutionalization, using quantitative metrics of productivity and qualitative analyses of labor relations.
CO5: Apply the concept of contingent labor to analyze labor contracts in a global supply‑chain firm, drafting a policy recommendation to improve worker dignity and reduce precarity.

CO6: Critically assess the impact of the 19th‑century industrial revolutions on contemporary entrepreneurship models by preparing a research essay that synthesizes historical transformations with present‑day technological entrepreneurship practices.

Course Description: This course provides a comprehensive introduction to the fundamental operational and design problems of modern Wireless Communications systems. It begins with a review of digital communication basics and an overview of current wireless standards and generations. The core curriculum delves into channel modeling, focusing on multipath propagation, pathloss, and various types of fading (frequency and time selectivity). It then progresses to essential mitigation techniques, covering the design and performance analysis of spatial, time, and frequency diversity techniques. The course concludes with advanced topics, including Multiple-Input Multiple-Output (MIMO) communication systems, capacity analysis, and a detailed examination of Orthogonal Frequency-Division Multiplexing (OFDM) and Massive MIMO, preparing students to design and evaluate rate and error performance of multi-antenna transceivers.
Detailed Syllabus: Unit 1: Review of digital communication, optimal detection, overview of wireless communication generations and standards
Unit 2: Channel modeling; Multipath propagation; pathloss and fading; types of fading; frequency and time selectivity
Unit 3: Diversity techniques; spatial, time and frequency diversity; performance analysis of various diversity techniques
Unit 4: MIMO communication systems; capacity analysis; MIMO receivers
Unit 5: OFDM, massive MIMO, multiuser communication
Generated_LOs: CO1: Analyze and quantify the impact of multipath propagation on OFDM subcarrier error probability under Rayleigh fading conditions.
CO2: Design a spatial diversity scheme using orthogonal space‑time block codes and evaluate its BER performance over a simulated MIMO channel.
CO3: Implement a frequency-selective root‑raised cosine equalizer in MATLAB to mitigate intersymbol interference in a simulated OFDM system.
CO4: Evaluate the capacity gains of a massive MIMO uplink employing zero‑forcing detection across varying antenna-to-user ratios.
CO5: Construct a channel model incorporating both pathloss and log-normal shadowing for a 5G urban microcell, and simulate its effect on link budget.
CO6: Demonstrate the end-to-end design of a multiuser OFDM‑MIMO transmission chain, including pilot allocation, channel estimation, and precoding, and validate performance through MATLAB simulations.
